title: Play It As It Lays
review:
I know what nothing means, and keep on playing.

Didion writes like an artist. This book was a beautiful sample of the English language ... although also like a powerful drug. It feels so hallucinatory and at a loss with reality—but then again, perhaps art is supposed to show that alternative world to us. The characters are so dysfunctional and yet so capable of existence in their society. This is the type of book that reminds us that it's really never that deep .... that we should play it as it lays.

title: The Body Artist
review:
Is reality too powerful for you?

Pure mastery and tactile feeling in the language of this book. However ... this book definitely strayed further to the edges of art, perhaps stretched and contorted itself a bit too far. I feel like I can sense the vague pulsing idea behind it, but it really was an absolute fever dream to read. 

--------------------------------------------------------

The answer to life is the movies.

Take the risk. Believe what you see and hear. It's the pulse of every secret intimation you've ever felt around the edges of your life.

title: The Bonesetter's Daughter
review: beautiful story written in such a vivid real way. Tan has such a gift for pulling out details that so closely resemble life. this book resonated with me because of so many shared experiences, some parts were absolutely heart-wrenching. my attention span has been absolutely destroyed so I felt that this novel was a bit long, but I don't regret drudging through it.

title: Stoner
review: incredible masterpiece. coming back for full thoughts later

title: The Vegetarian
review: placeholder :' ) will review soon

title: A Philosophical Enquiry into the Origin of Our Ideas of the Sublime and Beautiful
review:
“As the rose-tree is composed of the sweetest flowers and the sharpest thorns, as the heavens are sometimes overcast—alternately tempestuous and serene—so is the life of man intermingled with hopes and fears, with joys and sorrows, with pleasure and pain.”

I enjoyed the principal theory behind this book more than the book itself. I love the idea of the sublime — finding the ultimate beauty when in contrast against terror. However, the execution of this book was quite a dense exploration of the idea and went completely over my head. Self-initiated thinking about the ideas of the sublime and beautiful is a much better experience than absorbing it from this book.

----------------------------------------------

Nothing tends more to the corruption of science than to suffer it to stagnate. These waters must be troubled, before they can exert their virtues

title: A Visit from the Goon Squad
review:
Time's a goon, right?

Objectively some of the most masterful use of the English language I've ever witnessed. Certain passages of this book are writing in pure art form. Feeling grateful to have been able to read this in its native language, English.

This book borders on the verge of abstraction v.s. realism in writing form ... I couldn't tell what was happening half the time but I guess that adds to the intrigue and mystique. Overall I can see how this impressed the literary critics and won the Pulitzer Prize, and I don't regret powering through the dregs of the middle to get to the brutally honest and reflective ending. 

In another world this would have gotten five stars, but I don't think I'm in the right headspace right now to fully enjoy this strange artistry. Would recommend reading when you are in the mood to fully ruminate on life and art and their mysterious meanings. 

----------------------------------------------------------------

Suicide is a weapon; that we all know. But what about an art?

Her rebellion and hurt had melted away, deliquesced into a sweet, eternal sunniness that was terrible in the way that life would be terrible, Ted supposed, without death to give it gravitas and shape.

title: Kim Jiyoung, Born 1982
review:
“The world had changed a great deal, but the little rules, contracts and customs had not, which meant the world hadn't actually changed at all.”

A beautiful, gripping story about one woman's life, struggling with family relationships, her career, and existing as a woman in Korean society. I appreciate the feminist lens through which it criticizes Korean gender standards, but adding in explicit gender statistics about Korean society felt out of place. It really felt like beating the reader over the head instead of allowing them to absorb it themselves through the story.

title: What We Talk About When We Talk About Love
review:
'What do any of us really know about love?' 'It seems to me we're just beginners at
love.'

Stories with a beautiful, terrifying emptiness tied to the mundanity of everyday life. Carver has such a talent for magnifying the regular human existence into something uncanny that can be viewed as an art piece. I imagine these stories as the written version of Edward Hopper's seemingly ordinary, yet haunting, paintings.

title: Kitchen
review:
When was it I realized that, on this truly dark and solitary path we all walk, the only way we can light is our own?

Beautiful because it is artistic in such a unique way. The author's love of kitchens is truly admirable ... it's nice to see what can be viewed as precious art in others' eyes. Not extremely memorable, but still a lovely experience to listen to, uniquely Japanese in its solitary reflections and detail into everyday life.

-------------------------------------------------------------------

If a person hasn't ever experienced true despair, she grows old never knowing how to evaluate where she is in life; never understanding what joy really is. I'm grateful for it.

No matter what, I want to continue living with the awareness that I will die. Without that, I am not alive. 

Just when one can't take any more, one sees the moonlight. Beauty that seems to infuse itself into the heart: I know about that.

title: Wind/Pinball: Two Novels
review:
All things pass. None of us can manage to hold on to anything. In that way, we live our lives.

3.5/5

One of Murakami's earliest novels, a bit rawer than his later ones but still containing the quintessential beauty of internal dialogue found in all of his work. The plot is certainly strange, but it mirrors real life and shines a light on the mundane in such a refreshing way. Objectively I think this is a wonderful book, so maybe I'm only rating it three ish stars because his other ones have managed to leave a much deeper impression on me.

As only his 2nd novel ever, this is an extremely impressive stroke of literary genius, as if a baseball had just fallen from the sky and endowed Murakami with the ability to write. (Spoiler: it kind of did...)

--------------------------------------------------------

Writing is, in effect, the act of verifying the distance between us and the things surrounding us. What we need is not sensitivity, but a measuring stick.

Ascribing meaning to life is a piece of cake compared to actually living it.

Civilization is communication. That which is not expressed, doesn't exist.

Sometimes I imagine how great it would be if we could live our lives without bothering other people.

Just about anything looks better from a distance.

Is there anything in this world that can't be lost?

title: The Memory Police
review:
People, and I'm no exception, seem capable of forgetting almost anything.

Beautiful and intriguing as a story, but unfortunately the meaning was a bit lost on me. The premise itself—the population of entire island slowing losing their memory—is fascinating and makes you want to keep on reading, but the ending was a very unsatisfying confusion for me. 

It creates an interesting dialogue around memory but ... for what point, I sadly didn't understand.

title: All the Lovers in the Night
review:
Why does the night have to be so beautiful? Because at night, only half the world remains.

Beautifully written escape into the solitary life of a single woman, far removed from the social pressures and stigmas of the life that I find myself living right now. This is a book hooked on fantasies and ideas, promising a tantalizing dream that perhaps never becomes manifested into reality. 

Perhaps that's why I didn't like it as much—because instead of satisfying the sublime desire I crave from fiction, this story delivers a very pragmatic reminder ... a call back to Earth. 

---------------------------------------------

People here confuse boredom and stagnation with peace and safety.

title: Tell Them of Battles, Kings, and Elephants
review:
Beauty comes from abandoning the refuge of the old forms for the uncertainty of the present.

This book feels like it is written from another age, a rare treat in writing style and subject matter that feels so uniquely Old World. It riffs on historical fiction of a brief side quest Michelangelo completed in Constantinople, with characters so rich and dimensional that I find it sad these interactions may not actually have happened.

The cover design sums it up beautifully: a story from a lost, beautiful age brought back into the modern world through the abstract brushstrokes and brilliant mind of Mathias Énard.

----------------------------------------------

It's work, above all. Talent is nothing without work. Try it, if you like.

I know that men are children who chase away their despair with anger, their fear with love ... They cling to stories, they shove them in front of them like banners ... You conquer people by telling them of battles, kings, elephants, and marvelous beings; by speaking to them about the happiness they will find beyond death, the bright light that presided over their birth, the angels wheeling around them, the demons menacing them, and love, love, that promise of oblivion and satiety.

title: Cannery Row (Cannery Row, #1)
review:
Who wants to be good, if he has to be hungry too?

A beautiful slice-of-life rendition of a gritty, working class town. Steinbeck always masterfully crafts characters who are a mix of the light and the dark, a reflection of the complexity of real human psyches. There are no heroes or villains, perhaps only the cruelty of the system that manipulates them. 

Steinbeck's writing is set against such harsh conditions that it always becomes fiercely optimistic. There is no other way to view the glass than half-full.

-------------------------------------------------------------

The things we admire in men, kindness and generosity, openness, honesty, understanding and feeling are the concomitants of failure in our system. And those traits we detest, sharpness, greed, acquisitiveness, meanness, egotism and self-interest are the traits of success. And while men admire the quality of the first they love the produce of the second.

title: The Sun Also Rises
review:
We could have had such a damned good time together.

Yes, isn't it pretty to think so?

This was a beautifully written experience. Hemingway has such a crisp mastery of the English language that was such a treat to read (or, in my audiobook case, listen) to. 

A story full of passion, and warm dripping colors, and the salt of cruel heat. It's quite intriguing to take a peek into the colorful life at the time, but also a little disturbing to witness the sheer amount of gluttony involved. Days full of elite leisure, of not needing to worry about livelihood, seem a requirement to produce this kind of art. Even the ability to consume this type of art is a luxury. Inevitably, unfortunately, that reduced my respect for this book quite a bit. But I guess this decadence applies to nearly all literature, so it's unfair of me to judge.

----------------------------------------------------------

“I can't stand it to think my life is going so fast and I'm not really living it.” “Nobody ever lives their life all the way up except bull-fighters.”

No, nobody ever knows anything.

You paid some way for everything that was any good.

If you want people to like you, you have only to spend a little money.

You know it makes one feel rather good deciding not to be a bitch. Yes. It's sort of what we have instead of God.

title: The Hour of the Star
review:
And even sadness was also something for rich people, for people who could afford it, for people who didn't have anything better to do. Sadness was a luxury. 

A brief, beautiful breeze of a book that I finished in a single day. This is what I imagine an abstract painting would look like in book form. Bits and pieces of random thoughts that, stitched together, form a wandering story. I'm not exactly sure what happened in this book, but it leaves you with a feeling of artistry and a return to pure, unconscious stream-of-thought.

title: Never Enough: From Barista to Billionaire
review:
The twentieth spoon full of ice cream never quite hits like the first.

A fascinating firsthand look into what it's like to be a billionaire. Wilkinson dishes (most of) it all out. A great book to learn how to develop the mindset of a businessman, tapping into those soft skills that textbooks can't quite teach.

The book does feel honest and not too ghostwritten, but Wilkinson does tend to have a bit of an ego and is quite out of touch with the way he talks about money. (e.g. only half a million dollars?) The title itself is telling enough, because it seems to be the exact opposite of the altruistic contentment he advocates for by the end of the book. Some people are just wired to be hungry, great businessmen, and Wilkinson seems to be one of them.

I quite enjoyed it just because it opened my eyes to the many inner workings of a company (and many potential failures) that I haven't personally yet experienced. It's inspiring to see a designer become a billionaire for once.

----------------------------------------

The big money is not in the buying or selling, but in the waiting.

A business was, at its core, about solving problems for other people.

My sales technique was simple. Be fun to drink with, and ask a ton of questions.

At conferences I quickly started to learn that the most important business connections were made in bars, gossiping with drunk executives. Buying a round of drinks often generated a huge return on investment.

You don't know who's swimming naked until the tide goes out.

I realized through it all that in Silicon Valley everyone plays nice, wearing goofy hoodies and padding around in Allbirds, looking like friendly college kids. But inside, most were just as ruthless as their Wall Street counterparts. I soon came to prefer the super-direct pseudo-assholes I worked for over the fake magnanimous ones.

It's not enough to do what you love. You also have to stop doing what you hate. 

The tallest blade of grass is first to get cut.

Either it's hell yeah, or it's no.

title: Madonna in a Fur Coat
review:
The essence of life is in solitude – wouldn’t you agree? All unions are built on falsehood. People can only get to know each other up to a point and then they make up the rest, until one day, seeing their mistake, they turn their backs on sadness and run away. 

Devastating, but spectacular. So rarely is an artist at the peak of their craft like this. This book flows so beautifully and richly in a way that I haven't seen in a while. It was a real treat that I couldn't stop myself from reading greedily, but unfortunately it did leave me in a terrible cloud for a few days from the depressing, but romantic, heartbreak. 

I think this is what Kafka meant when he said that A book must be the axe for the frozen sea within us.

------------------------------------

Can there be any sweeter intoxication than exerting power and authority over your own kind?

I had yet to learn that nothing in this world can ever match the marvels that we conjure up in our own minds.

To pity another is to assume superiority. 

For our lives were governed by trivial details. Indeed, trivial details were what true life was made of. The logic in our minds had always been at odds with the logic of life itself.

title: Heaven
review:
When you really look at what's going on, everyone's living in their own world.

A secret wonderful treat. This book comes from the same beautiful tortured realm of Murakami. At times it almost feels like trauma porn, too overly indulgent ... but still raises some interesting deep philosophies about life because of it.  All I can say is that I am extremely glad that I never read this in high school.

This book offers a refreshing glimpse into that uniquely Japanese tendency to live completely inside your own head, in your own world. Very rare and precious. 

------------------------------------

I wonder if anyone can ever actually stop thinking.

What matters is that all the pain, and all the sadness, have meaning. 

People are always dying. It's a perfect truth. 

Living is really just waiting to die. And if that's true, why bother living at all?

Nobody does anything because they have the right. They do it because they want to.

If anything has meaning, everything does. And if nothing has meaning, nothing does.

title: An Ideal Husband
review:
Only dull people are brilliant at breakfast.

Comedic truth. Such a fun experience, especially as an audiobook when the characters are played by quite famous actors/actresses with the most satisfying delicious accents.

-----------------------------

You have never been poor, and never known what ambition is.

Morality is simply the attitude we adopt toward people whom we personally dislike.

It is not the perfect, but the imperfect, who have need of love.

To love oneself is the beginning of a lifelong romance.

title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
review: Really quite a curious book ... I wonder how Fitzgerald even came up with this concept. A short, fascinating little exploration on the strange concept of age.

title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
review: absolutely iconic but ... unfortunately felt a bit too long and convoluting for me. I couldn't keep track of all the characters and the crazy whimsical magical happenings. I know there must be themes and deep meanings hidden within this book, but sadly I was too busy being confused to pick up on any of them. Perhaps it was reader error, but this book unfortunately did not develop into the magical experience I had heard it could be.

title: Blink: The Power of Thinking Without Thinking
review:
We need to respect the fact that it is possible to know without knowing why we know and accept that — sometimes — we're better off that way.

Fascinating argument favoring split-second blink decisions over prolonged, calculated reasoning. Gladwell is just a captivating author—even though this is non-fiction, it feels like you're having a conversation with him as he brings up story after story to prove his point. Perhaps a bit too long and rambling at points (defeats the whole point of a split-second blink) lol but overall I highly enjoyed this. Any Gladwell book is always a lovely treat to read. 

------------------------------------------------------------

In the act of tearing something apart, you lose its meaning.

The big giant is tied down by those little rules and regulations and procedures. And the little guy? He just runs around and does what he wants.

title: Total Recall: My Unbelievably True Life Story
review:
After that, I never went to a competition to compete. I went to win. Even though I didn’t win every time, that was my mind-set. I became a total animal.

Champion Bodybuilder. ✅ A-list actor. ✅ Governor of California. ✅ If his resume doesn't prove it already, this book might—this man is the real deal. A disciplined machine (or animal, as he says) with superhuman pain tolerance against the obstacles of achieving his crystal-clear visions. He drops all the secrets to his success so freely here—it's very inspiring to share in his huge hunger, whetting our own. Of course he has his extreme flaws too; there's always the smooth sanguine pride necessary for survival in politics/business/Hollywood, and it is very hard to get over the fact that he cheated on his wife. But the sheer human effort he put into achieving his goals sets a rock-hard example. He was someone who was truly in touch with his inner desires and did what was required to manifest them out into the world. 

This book could have used some cutting and sometimes seems play-by-play ghostwritten—but there's probably a reason why Schwarzenegger did not choose writing as a profession. This book tells a fascinating, otherworldly, and superhuman story. The craziest part is that it's true.

---------------------------------------------

CHAPTER 1

[My father's] answer to life was discipline ... I never felt that I was good enough, strong enough, smart enough. He let me know that there was always room for improvement. A lot of sons would have been crippled by his demands, but instead the discipline rubbed off on me. I turned it into drive.”

The vision became so clear in my mind that I felt like it had to happen. There was no alternative. It was this, or nothing.

CHAPTER 3

I didn't mind basic training. It taught me that something that seems impossible at the start can be achieved.

CHAPTER 4

After that, I never went to a competition to compete. I went to win. Even though I didn’t win every time, that was my mind-set. I became a total animal.

But I was wild only when I was wild. When it was time to train, I never missed a session.

'The limit is in your mind,' he said. 'Think about it.' And he was right. The limit I thought existed was purely psychological. Now that I've seen someone doing 1000 pounds, I started making leaps in my training. It showed the power of mind over body.

CHAPTER 5

I was amazed by how much Americans liked to celebrate. I'd never celebrated a birthday until I came to America. I'd never even seen a cake with candles. 

CHAPTER 8

It might seem I was handcuffing myself by setting such specific goals, but it was actually just the opposite. I found it liberating. Knowing exactly where I wanted to end up freed me totally to improvise how to get there.

I learned that staying on top of the hill is harder than climbing it.

Often it's easier to make a decision when you don't know as much because then you can't overthink.

CHAPTER 9

Just remember when they say no, you hear yes—and act accordingly. Someone says to you, 'We can't do this movie,' you hug him and say, 'Thank you for believing in me.'

CHAPTER 10

I liked the idea of staying hungry in life, and never staying in one place.

CHAPTER 11

But I believe that the only way you become a leading man is by treating yourself like a leading man and working your ass off. If you don't believe in yourself, then how will anyone else believe in you?

CHAPTER 14

Look at the faces of people who went through horrible times. Look at the lines, the character in their faces. You can't fake that. These people have principles that they will stand and die for.

CHAPTER 15

My definition of living is to have excitement always. That's the difference between living and existing.

CHAPTER 16

Don't go where it's crowded. Go where it's empty. Even though it's harder to get there, that's where you belong, and where there's less competition.

I had a new vision in front of me, and I always feel that if I can see it, and believe it, then I can achieve it.

CHAPTER 17

The more you know, the less you tend to do something.

I'm always comparing life to a climb, not just because there's struggle, but also because I find at least as much joy in the climbing as in reaching the top.

You can have the greatest movie in the world, but if you don't get it out there, if people don't know about it, you have nothing.

Same with bodybuilding, same with politics. No matter what I did in life, I was aware that you had to sell it. 

CHAPTER 18

If you do something, you want to do it well.

CHAPTER 23

I never argued with people who underestimated me. If the accent and the muscles and the movies made people think I was stupid, it worked to my advantage.

CHAPTER 29

You'll get more for being a peacemaker than a warrior.

CHAPTER 30

Arnold's Rules:

 •  Turn your liabilities into assets. 
    It's easier to stand out when you aim straight for the top.
 •  Never follow the crowd. Go where it's empty. 
 •  No matter what you do in life, selling is part of it. 

“Every time I meet a great person—and I never pass up the chance—I try to ask how they made good and to figure out the angle that has worked for them. I know that there are a thousand keys to success and I love distilling new rules from my experiences and theirs.”

(selections from) 10 PRINCIPLES:

 • Never let pride get in your way.

 • Don't overthink.

If you think all the time, the mind cannot relax. The key thing is to let both the mind and the body float. This doesn't mean that you shouldn't use your brain, but part of us also needs to go through life instinctively. By not analyzing everything, you get rid of all the garbage that loads you up and bogs you down.

Turning off your mind is an art.

The more knowledge you have, the more you are free to rely on your instincts.

The more you know, the more you hesitate, which is why even the smartest people blow it big time.

A boxer brings a huge amount of knowledge to the ring. But if he were to think about any of those when the punch comes, it would be over. He has to use what he knows in a tenth of a second. When you are not confident of your decision-making process, it will slow you down.

  • Forget Plan B.

“If you’re anxious, instead of making fallback plans, think about the worst that can happen if you fail. How bad would it be? You quickly find out it’s really nothing.”

 • Don't blame your parents. 

“Sometimes you have to appreciate the very people and circumstances that traumatized you. Today I hail the strictness of my father, and my whole upbringing, and the fact that I didn’t have anything that I wanted in Austria, because those were the very factors that made me hungry.”

 • Stay hungry. 

“My father always told me, “Be useful. Do something.” He was right. If you have a talent or skill that makes you happy, use it to improve your neighborhood. And if you feel a desire to do more, then go all out. You’ll have plenty of time to rest when you’re in the grave. Live a risky life and a spicy life and like Eleanor Roosevelt said, every day do something that scares you.”

title: The Prince
review: probably really good if you want to learn how to be a prince. if you’re a regular citizen in the 21st century, strip away all the historical fluff and this can probably teach you how to be a really good CEO or corporate manipulator.

title: Where the Crawdads Sing
review: finished this entire book in one sitting. incredible raw writing, the first time I've cried at a book in more than a year. there is some sort of special energy in this writing.

title: Dandelion Wine
review:
Dandelion Wine is nothing if it is not the boy-hid-in-the-man playing in the fields of the Lord on the green grass of other Augusts in the midst of starting to grow up, grow old, and sense darkness waiting under the trees to seed the blood.

Flashback to my 7th grade self discovering this on a shelf in the school library and picking it up only to get through the first chapter ... but even 7 years ago I knew that this writing was absolutely delectable, truly peak art. It was a bit too strong for me back then, but returning to it now (god, 7 years later), I can appreciate it for a much deeper meaning. Life has changed so much since then, going in exactly the opposite way that Bradbury advocates for. This book is like a time machine, back to a golden early age of American culture, before the flashy extreme capitalism and materialism, when good people were quite literally the salt of the earth. 

So sad but inevitable to see the way that times have changed. This book should have unlocked something strange and tender inside me ... but I'm so caught up in my busy, rushed ways that I couldn't let it truly sink in. Life has changed a lot since 7th grade. Now that I finally can understand this book, I can't take the time to enjoy it.

--------------------------------------------

And, after all, isn’t that what life is all about, the ability to go around back and come up inside other people’s heads to look out at the damned fool miracle and say: oh, so that’s how you see it!?

A walk on a spring morning is better than an eighty-mile ride in a hopped-up car, you know why? Because it's full of flavors, full of a lot of things growing. You've time to seek and find.

And when you're all to yourself that way, you're really yourself for a little while; you get to thinking things through, alone.

title: The Elephant Vanishes
review:
A thing's too close, and you miss it.

The perfect book to play Murakami bingo with—cats, beautifully formed ears, deep holes/wells, lonesome main characters. This was a short story collection with a few Murakami classics (e.g. the short story version of WUBC) + a few more obscure ones (like the titular The Elephant Vanishes).

Maybe I just wasn't in the mood for Murakami at the moment, but most of these did not strike a chord with me as they usually do. These stories were still a lovely joy to get through, but unfortunately not much resonated. This little book just offered a brief escape into Murakami's perfectly balanced literary world, as always.

------------------------------------------------------------------

Sleep

Maybe death is a kind of rest, but reasoning can’t tell us that. The only way to find out what death is is to die. Death can be anything at all.

Barn Burning

A thing's too close, and you miss it.

The Silence

One of the things I like about boxing is the depth. That’s what grabbed me. Compared to that, hitting and getting his is no big deal. That’s only the outcome. The same with winning or losing. If you could get to the bottom of the depth, losing doesn’t matter—nothing can hurt you.

If you make the effort, you get back what you put in.

title: Tell Me Everything
review:
5 stars purely out of respect for the sheer amount of SH*T that this woman has been through. 

Absolutely ghostwritten & amateurish at times, yes. But ... it's still got that same kind of heartwrenching power as A Little Life. Except this story is actually true.

title: Greenlights
review:
Wow never knew Matthew McConaughey was such a poet — listening to this as an audiobook was a highly-recommend-10/10 experience because he narrates the pulsing lilt of his own words in a such a unique and lively way. 

Very much can see how this man has the worldliness/talent/genius to have won an Oscar, started his own production company, and also created his own music label — this book is filled with so many gems of wisdom and is such an exhilarating fun time.

Only docked a star (would have docked only .5 if Goodreads let me) because I really did not like the last section of the book where he signs off and tries desperately to tie this book into the present day (post-2020)... that writing seemed so stilted and unnatural, like a nice neat wrap-up forced onto him by the publisher. A bad, careless ending that defied the whole free-spirit point of the entire book.

Favorite quotes:

Less impressed, more involved.

It is not about being right or wrong, it is about understanding each other...Take notes America!

title: All the Light We Cannot See
review:
Wow. This is a book that you will suck up greedily and try to finish all in one sitting. It reads like a beautiful painting. The right texture, the presence—you can really feel all the heart and energy put into this. Magical. True mastery of the craft. I accidentally sped through the entire thing in two days because I couldn't resist, but damn I wish I had given it more time just to let everything seep more beautifully into my mind and its subconscious. This book restores hope to a slower, purer form of life where everything is valued, and loved, just a bit more.

CHAPTER I

So how, children, does the brain, which lives without a spark of light, build for us a world full of light?

Only through the hottest fires can purification be achieved.

You know the greatest lesson of history? It’s that history is whatever the victors say it is. Whoever wins, that’s who decides the history. We act in our own self-interest. Of course we do. Name me a person or a nation who does not. The trick is figuring out where your interests are.

CHAPTER 4

After a while, he is learning, even total darkness is not quite darkness.

CHAPTER 5

A real diamond, his father used to say, is never entirely free of inclusions. A real diamond is never perfect.

She remembers something her father said back in Paris, on the first night of the invasion, as they waited for a train. Everyone is looking out for himself.

“Do you know what happens, Etienne, when you drop a frog in a pot of boiling water? It jumps out. But do you know what happens when you put the frog in a pot of cool water and then slowly bring it to a boil? You know what happens then? The frog cooks.”

CHAPTER 7

The total entropy of any system, said Dr. Hauptmann, will decrease only if the entropy of another system will increase. Nature demands symmetry.

It strikes Werner just then as wondrously futile to build splendid buildings, to make music, to sing songs, to print huge books full of colorful birds in the face of the seismic, engulfing indifference of the world—what pretensions humans have! Why bother to make music when the silence and wind are so much larger?

CHAPTER 10 

When I lost my sight, Werner, people said I was brave. When my father left, people said I was brave. But it is not bravery; I have no choice. I wake up and live my life. Don’t you do the same?

CHAPTER 12

It is the obliviousness of our children that saves us.

title: Circe
review:
Excellent.

Perdita Weeks has such a beautiful voice. Madeline Miller is really a genius, such a rare and skilled worldbuilder. Myths/stories/morals really are eternal. 

Beneath the smooth, familiar face of things is another that waits to tear the world in two. 

The fragility of mortals bred kindness, and good grace. They knew how to value friendship and an open hand.

But perhaps no parent can truly see their child. When we look we see only the mirror of our own faults.

I thought once that gods are the opposite of death. But I see now that they are more dead than anything, for they are unchanging and can hold nothing in their hands.

title: The Goldfinch
review:
Wow. Absolutely beautiful. All the secrets to life, and art, and love, and pain are in this book. Donna Tartt lives up to her literary genius label; words flow and shine in a way that I haven't seen from any other author. Audiobook experience was wonderful; David Pittu brings everything to life at exactly the right pace, really sucks you away. Can drag on at times (maybe the editor was too nice by not wanting to slash out the unneeded, even if well-written, descriptions), but still. Wow.

Idolatry. Caring too much for objects can destroy you. Only, if you care for a thing enough, it takes on a life of its own, doesn't it? And isn't the whole point of things, beautiful things, that they connect you to some larger beauty? Those first images that crack your heart wide open and you spend the rest of your life chasing, or trying to recapture, in one way or another.
_____________

Long version:

Wow wow wow. Where to even begin. In every work of genius we recognize our own rejected thoughts; they come back to us with a certain alienated majesty. Emerson was right when he said that. This book feels so close, an experience so connected to my own heart (and I'm sure hundreds of thousands of others). Crazy how that can happen, when it details the life of a very specific boy in a very specific environment that I would be lightyears from experiencing in my own reality. But still there were so many moments I had to rewind and bookmark because they felt too real: beautiful, universal truths written defiantly, matter-of-factly in the dirty grunge of the world and cruel life. 

Donna Tartt must have had a very sensitive upbringing, where she was exposed to a great amount of experiences (many of those available only to those with extreme wealth) and was able to learn the fine art of appreciating art. That shines through in her writing. Only those who do not have to worry about eating their next meal, or making a desparate salary, have time to let themselves think about experiencing the sublime through art or literature or music. Thinking too much like that can be so, so dangerous—when the mind does not have hard, stupid work to do and is left to wander luxuriously, it often leads its owner to the psych ward. 10000000% the main character could belong in a psych ward, and Tartt writes too vividly to not at least know what it's like to have thoughts like these herself.

But still she does occupy herself with the good, honest, needed work of writing and presents us with this beautiful book. 10 years of her life, finished in only 14 days of mine. In this book was a complete, confident, shining world that she built—truly letting us see the world how she sees it, without the distractions and confusions of someone who isn't as sure or settled spiritually into their own worldview as she most magnificently is. Everything feels right and natural, full of life. Tackling the same themes as David Foster Wallace, or David Lynch, or John Steinbeck, or Haruki Murakami, or anyone else who gets to the heart of balance and equilibrium and nirvana in life. Maybe I'm cherry-picking and letting my own reality get distorted by a strange faith in The Way, or some kind of big power in the universe, but this book reflects everything perfectly and, most importantly, beautifully. I loved it.

 Part I - Ch 1 
They want it all as detailed as possible, because whenever you see flies, or insects in a still life—a wilted petal, a black spot on the apple, the painter is giving you a secret message. He's telling you that living things don't last. It's all temporary. Death, in life.

 Part I - Ch 4 
What mattered more was the feeling. A rich, sweet undertone so demanding that in class, on the schoolbus, lying in bed trying to think of something safe, or pleasant, some environment or configuration where my chest wasn't tight with anxiety. All I had to do was sink into the bloodwarm current and let myself spin away to the secret place where everything was alright. 

 Part II - Ch 5 
The mass of men lead lives of quiet desperation. A stereotyped but unconscious despair is concealed, even under what are called the gains and amusements of mankind. 

 Part II - Ch 6 
And though, in the clockless, temperature-controlled casino night, words like day and Christmas were fairly meaningless constructs, happiness, amidst the loudly clinked glasses didn't seem quite such a doomed or fatal idea.

 Part III - Ch 7 
We are so accustomed to disguise ourselves to others, that in the end, we become disguised to ourselves. - François de La Rochefoucauld

 Part IV - Ch 9 
Objective value, list value, was meaningless. If a customer came in clueless with money in hand, as most of them did, it didn't matter what the book said, what the expert said, what similar items at Christie's had recently gone for. An object, any object, was worth whatever you could get someone to pay for it.

When selling a piece, talking it up (as opposed to sitting back and permitting the unwary to wander into my trap) was a game: to size up a customer and figure out the image they wanted to project. Not so much the people they were—know-it-all decorator, New Jersey housewife, self-conscious gay man—as the people they wanted to be. Even on the highest levels it was all smoke and mirrors.

 Part IV - Ch 10 
And it was awful to learn, by having it so suddenly vanish from under me, that all my adult life I'd been privately sustained by a great, hidden, savage joy—the conviction that my whole life was balanced atop a secret that might, at any moment, blow it apart.

What you want, to live and be happy in the world, is a woman who has her own life, and lets you have yours.

To understand the world at all, sometimes you could only focus on a tiny bit of it, look very hard at what was close to hand, and make it stand in for the whole. 

 Part V - Ch 11 
We have art in order not to die from the truth. - Nietzsche

And in whatever wink of consciousness that remained to me, I felt I understood the secret grandeur of dying. All the knowledge held back from all humankind until the very end. No pain, no fear, magnificent detachment. Lying in state upon the death barge, and receding into grand immensities like an emperor. Gone. Gone. Observing all the distant scurriers on shore. Freed from all the old human pettiness of love, and fear, and grief. And death. 

 Part V - Ch 12 
It's never the way it seems—all good, all bad. So much easier if it was.

Because, what I am trying to say, what I was thinking in the car from Antwerp last night—good doesn't always follow from good deeds. Nor bad deeds result from bad, does it. Even the wise and good cannot see the end of all actions. Scary idea. 

Why be good? But—this is what took hold of me last night driving here in the car: what if more complicated than that? What if maybe opposite was true as well? Because if bad can sometimes come from good actions, where does it ever say anywhere that only bad can come from bad actions? Maybe sometimes the wrong way is the right way? You can take the wrong path and it still comes out where you want to be?

Well, I have to say I personally have never drawn such a sharp line between good and bad as you. For me, that line is often false. The two are never disconnected. One can't exist without the other. 

As long as I am acting out of love I feel I am doing best I know how. 

You don't need a point. The point is maybe that the point is too big to see or work around to on our own. 

The reason I'd liked Boris, and felt happy around him from almost the moment I'd met him, is that he was never afraid. You didn't meet many people who moved freely through the world with such a vigorous contempt for it. And, at the same time, such oddball and unthwartable faith in what, in childhood, he had liked to call 'the planet of Earth.'

You know what Picasso says: 'Bad artists copy, good artists steal.' Still, with real greatness there's a jolt at the end of the wire. It doesn't matter how often you grab hold of the line, or how many people have grabbed hold of it before you. It's the same line, fallen from a higher life.

Dreams, and signs. Past, and future. Luck, and fate. There wasn't a 'single' meaning. There were many meanings. It was a riddle, expanding out, and out, and out. 

Idolatry. Caring too much for objects can destroy you. Only, if you care for a thing enough, it takes on a life of its own, doesn't it? And isn't the whole point of things, beautiful things, that they connect you to some larger beauty? Those first images that crack your heart wide open and you spend the rest of your life chasing, or trying to recapture, in one way or another.

And the great majority of people it'll never strike in any deep way at all, but a really great painting is fluid enough to work its way into the mind and heart. To all kinds of different angles. In ways that are unique. And very particular. Yours. Yours. I was painted for you.

Beauty alters the grain of reality. 

And I keep thinking too of the more conventional wisdom—namely, that the pursuit of pure beauty is a trap. A fast track to bitterness and sorrow. That beauty has to be wedded to something more meaningful. Only, what is that thing? Why am I made the way I am? Why do I care about all the wrong things, and nothing at all for the right ones? Or, to tip it another way, how can I see so clearly that everything I love or care about is illusion—and yet, for me anyway, all that's worth living for lies in that charm?

It's not about outward appearances, but inward significance. A grandeur in the world, but not of the world. A grandeur that the world doesn't understand. That first glimpse of pure otherness, in whose presence you bloom out, and out, and out. A self one does not want. A heart one cannot help.

Because, if our secrets define us, as opposed to the face we show the world, then the painting was the secret that raised me above the surface of life. And enabled me to know who I am.

I think about something I read about Sargent. How, in portraiture, Sargent always looked for the animal in the sitter.

Paint is paint. And yet also feather and bone. It's the place where reality strikes the ideal. Or a joke becomes serious. And anything serious is a joke. The magic point where every idea and its opposite are equally true.

And I'm hoping there's some larger truth about suffering here. Or at least, my understanding of it. Although I've come to realize that the only truths that matter to me are the ones I don't, and can't, understand.

Because, here's the truth. Life is catastrophe. The basic fact of existence—of walking around trying to feed ourselves and find friends and whatever else we do—is catastrophe.

But does it make any sense at all to know that it ends badly for all of us? Even the happiest of us? And that we all lose everything that matters to us in the end? And yet to know as well, despite all this, as cruelly as the game is stacked, that it's possible to play it with a kind of joy? To try to make some meaning out of all this seems unbelievably quaint. Maybe I only see a pattern because I've been staring too long. But then again, to paraphrase Boris—maybe I see a pattern because it's there. 

And as much as I'd like to believe that there's a truth beyond illusion, I've come to believe that there's no truth beyond illusion. Because, between reality on the one hand, and the point where the mind strikes reality, there's a middle zone. A rainbow edge, where beauty comes into being. Where two very different surfaces mingle and blur to provide what life does not. And this is the space where all art exists. And all magic. And, perhaps I would argue as well, all love. 

And just as music is the space between notes, just as the stars are beautiful because of the space between them, just as the sun strikes raindrops at a certain angle, and throws a prism of color across the sky, so the space where I exist, and want to keep existing, and to be quite frank I hope I die in, is exactly this middle distance. Where despair struck pure otherness and created something sublime.

And that's why I've chosen to write these pages as I've written them. For only by stepping into the middle zone—the poly-chrome edge between truth and untruth—is it tolerable to be here, and writing this, at all.

Whatever teaches us to talk to ourselves is important. Whatever teaches ourselves to sing ourselves out of despair.

title: Rogues: True Stories of Grifters, Killers, Rebels and Crooks
review:
Radden Keefe is probably one of the most gifted journalists of this generation—the way he handles words in the intro to this book was incredible. Rogues is a collection of some of the most intriguing articles that PRK has written in his career. However, I fear that most of the articles in this book were just interesting stories that failed to resonate with me in terms of a deeper meaning. It just seems like he is recounting a play-by-play, something similar to what I could have gained from reading a Wikipedia article. 

I also found myself experiencing the same problem I had with his other book (Empire of Pain)—why write the book when the story isn't even finished? I wish that he had waited a bit to recount some of these stories with more resolution (especially the Bourdain article ...).

Overall, I still would read another Radden Keefe book just due to his sheer mastery of the writing skill—and out of respect for the beautiful deliciously way he rendered his story on Anthony Bourdain. If there is any article that you read in this book, let it be Anthony Bourdain's Moveable Feast.

title: In Praise of Shadows
review:
We find beauty not in the thing itself but in the patterns of shadows, the light and the darkness, that one thing against another creates.

An absolutely genius tidbit of a book (barely 100 pages) … on art, aesthetics, society, and the truths of life. Tanizaki presents a perspective so drastically different from the doctrines of the West. Who’s to say which perspective is correct … but as a society that champions the undeniable goodness of light, it is fascinating to remember the necessity of darkness as well.

This may be confirmation bias because I will gladly eat up every book that touches upon the concept of a yin-yang, but I found this to be a timeless masterpiece that still holds true 90 years later. Just imagine if Tanizaki had heard of these glowing little prisms of electric light that we call iPhones today … truly destroying the magical world of shadows.

title: The City and Its Uncertain Walls
review:
People are like a breath. Their days are like a fleeting shadow.

The first Murakami book that I think has been destroyed by the modern age (e.g. the mention of Covid making him rethink and 3x the length of this book ... which I feel was unnecessary). If it wasn't for the fact that this was written by Murakami, I would never have been able to push myself to finish it. 

Even Murakami himself seems to notice and touch on this idea of modernity destroying art:

The world was, day by day, becoming a more convenient and unromantic place.
(one of the best lines from this book)

This story still has a beautiful strange meaning, but just one extremely subdued by the lack of focus that the modern age has inflicted on our brains. This novel could have been half its length (like he had originally intended)... the fact that he had to write an afterword to justify his writing choices—to say more, instead of less—feels tragic.

------------------------------------------------------------------

Maybe you're better off not knowing things you don't have to know.

Never give up believing. If you can believe strongly, deeply, in something, the road ahead will become clear.

Truth is not found in fixed stillness, but in ceaseless change and movement.

title: The Year of Magical Thinking
review:
And then, gone. In the midst of life we are in death.

So powerful and beautifully written, but unfortunately a little too insane for me to feel comfortable fully immersing myself in. (although that is the entire point of art I guess) Reader's error, not writer's error. I guess I had trouble connecting with this book because I have never experienced the death of loved ones, especially at the magnitude Joan was forced to. Overall, still a very powerful work of art—if you are willing to let it in. :' )

--------------------------------

Read, learn, work it up. Go to the literature. Information is control.

Grief turns out to be a place none of us know until we reach it.

I never saw a wild thing sorry for itself.

title: Crying in H Mart
review: A beautifully written memoir for sure, but unfortunately it didn't really do as much for me as I've been hearing from the internet, media, friends, etc. I had a hard time resonating with this book, although Michelle Zauner definitely has a very gifted way with words whether in songs or in writing. I think it's probably because my experiences growing up as an Asian American were so drastically different from hers: different area, different culture, & a completely different style of upbringing. I can see why a lot of people love this book though, and the motif of foods as a connection to culture and family is a nice touch.

title: Sputnik Sweetheart
review: so so belated but ... this book is exactly Murakami. Refreshing and beautiful, very strange ... meaningless and absolutely meaningful at the same time.

title: Grimm's Fairy Tales
review:
Lovely little escape into an older world with kings and princesses, where time passes slower and simply. Young girls have rosy cheeks with flowing hair and dinner can be a crust of bread and milk. 

Great, short, readable sentences accompanied by printed illustration plates. 

Many stories have very questionable morals though - mostly about staying submissive and admiring of wealthy monarchs in power. But I enjoyed those about the concrete existence of extreme karma. Kindness and wickedness are defined as sharply distinct and XOR in these stories (& the characters' fates fall in accordance with their behavior on the ends of these two extremes). I'm glad they reminded me of the days when I would choose kindness & hard work in poverty over wickedness & idleness in riches - and in these stories there is always gold or a prince waiting on the other side for those with a good heart.  

Also nice to read stories with a little more weight than some of their glorified Disney counterparts - the G in Grimm most definitely does not stand for General Audiences. 

Most enjoyed: The Elves and The Cobbler, Little Red Riding Hood, Snow-White and Rose-Red, Cinderella (but this one takes last place on the list because of the chopped-off toe and bloody heel) 

Most questionable morals: The Wolf and The Seven Goslings, The Three Luck Children, Briar Rose, The Gold Spinner, The Twelve Huntsmen, The Town Musicians

title: The Creative Act: A Way of Being
review:
When making art, we create a mirror in which someone may see their own hidden reflection.

Four stars just because there are so many undeniable beautiful truths in this book. The actual format was a bit uninteresting & hard to get through, but most of his musings touch very true aspects of the creative act. This book would have been more exciting with actual anecdotes or stories of how these diatribes manifest in the real world, instead of just a laundry list of instructions. (perhaps he's under NDA for his work with bigger artists? ... idk but that's still a very sad excuse)

The audiobook was a silly experience because it's basically a 4 hour lecture of Rubin indoctrinating his philosophy to you—with an echoing ding after every chapter from his gong.

--------------------------------------------------------

Though we can't change what it is that we're noticing, we can change our ability to notice.

The universe is only as large as our perception of it.

We're not playing to win, we're playing to play.

Darkness and light are only meaningful in relation with each other. Without one, the other wouldn't exist.

Good habits create good art. The way do anything is the way we do everything.

The best work is the work you're excited about.

The magic lives in the wonder of what we do not know.

title: When We Cease to Understand the World
review:
Oh goodness I'm so sorry goodreads. Bogged down asf so no time for a real review but: unfortunately, I ceased to understand the meaning of this book. It just seems like an artistic and highly fictionalized retelling of great scientific minds descending into madness. But why??? 

I literally could not pull a single worthwhile message from this book. But the title was poetic and promising at least!

title: Dance Dance Dance
review: I hate to say this but Murakami ,,, this is definitely not his brilliant spontaneous genius at its best. However, still solid. Like the main characters: just dance, dance, dance all the problems away ...

title: Siddhartha
review:
Soft is stronger than hard, water stronger than rock, love stronger than force.

Full of musings and universal truths (as expected) but also not about the actual Buddha Siddhartha (not as expected oops). A beautiful work of literature, but at times told a little too mythically for me to take it seriously. Very slow lives, very at peace. You can tell it was written from a different time that we are slowly losing. (Sad, but, as Siddhartha suggests, a truth we should accept as inevitable)

Everyone takes. Everyone gives. Such is life.

The opposite of every truth is just as true. 

Time is not real, Govinda, I have experienced this often and often again. And if time is not real, then the gap which seems to be between the world and the eternity, between suffering and blissfulness, between evil and good, is also a deception.

title: Room to Dream
review:
David Lynch is a wonderful film director but perhaps not the best book writer. The parts he narrates in the biography feel just like he is having a conversation with you though, which is lovely. 

The other biographer in this book seemed to be head over heels obsessed with him … she could not write a single bad thing about the man. Perhaps it would be better to have a dual view of both his good and evil qualities, like so many of the characters he creates.

title: Kokoro
review:
There is no such thing as a stereotype bad man in this world. Under normal conditions, everybody is more or less good, or, at least, ordinary. But tempt them, and they may suddenly change. That is what is so frightening about men.

Remarkable truths and observations about life and the nature of human beings. However, so depressing and futile that I really can't bump it up to 5 stars. How do people live with these thoughts, as the main characters do, and accomplish anything with their lives? Maybe it's my Western capitalism brainwashing kicking in, but I can't stand for this story of characters who just live off their inherited wealth and do nothing of value all day. If anything, perhaps Sōseki is trying to make a commentary on how living uselessly just leads to self-inflicted harms and death? And also perhaps a comment on the nature of human beings—neither inherently good nor bad, but just blank slates which over time the ruinous world can stain with dark terrible ink.

It's a bad thing not to have a struggle for one's living.

---------------------------------------

My heart, which until then had felt tight with pain and fear, seemed to find relief in sorrow.

title: The Setting Sun
review:
Only those who wish to go on living should. Just as man has the right to live, he ought also to have the right to die. 

Dazai writes like a genius, though unfortunately a very depressed one. This book is hideous, tortured, and yet still ... 'beautiful' isn't the right word, but something close to that. I remember loving his writing in high school because it was easy to share the same viewpoint as his characters. But when for some strange unshakable reason you now believe that life is worth living, you can't appreciate his writing in the same way. Anyone who takes this book to heart, and not as a work of art, might meet the same dangerous fate as the spoiled aristocrat main characters.

You can't seem to separate the art from the artist in the situation. Dazai is such a strange, strange man. So horrifyingly dark at times, yet also so full of gentle light.

Last year, nothing happened. The year before, nothing happened. And the year before that, nothing happened.

We all remain children, no matter how much time goes by. We don't understand anything.

title: Heartburn
review: Unfortunately not relatable at all. (I guess because I have never truly been in love or fallen out of a marriage) Had high hopes for it to turn into something meaningful because it was so highly recommended by Madeline Miller and a slew of other famous people, but unfortunately it just seemed like a lighthearted joke. I will say this was written in the 80s but could somewhat pass as a modern novel, so the writing is decent. Feels like you're having a conversation with a jaded housewife finally woken up by far-flung catastrophes striking in her life.

title: The Fall
review: This book takes unreliable narrator to the next level. There are probably some genius interesting philosophies hidden inside it that will make you rethink your whole life, but you have to work so hard to decipher them that sadly I just gave up. Camus is a master at using motifs and symbols to suggest crazy meanings though—the themes of this book seem very similar to The Stranger, except that one was nicer to read because it actually had a plot.

title: And Then There Were None
review:
mystery at its finest. what a labyrinthine masterpiece. magnum opus material for sure.

Sped through the entire thing in two days, literally couldn’t even resist spoiling it a quarter of the way through. Honestly I would almost recommend reading the Wikipedia page beforehand though … because damn you pick up SO many more masterfully placed details already knowing who orchestrated this delicate test of human evils.

title: A Field Guide to Getting Lost
review: I have been so horrid at keeping up on Goodreads

title: Men Without Women
review:
Nothing revitalizes my appreciation of life and rediscovery of freewill like Murakami. Even in short story format (or perhaps because of it), his writing is always genuinely the most sublime joy. It's like reverting back to the state of being a wide-eyed child with no shame, refusing to capitulate to the terrors of the world. This book was about loneliness, but not in a purely sad way at all. It's always an indulgent treat to immerse myself in Murakami's world, a world that fits my philosophies so perfectly—but sadly it's important to remember there is a difference between reality in books and reality in life. This was a beautiful short sweet treat—makes you think about and feel and notice so many new things. leaves a wonderful aftertaste.

--------------------------------------------------

'Tobacco's a killer.' 
'Being alive is a killer, if you think about it.'

Maybe working on the little things as dutifully and honestly as we can is how we stay sane when the world is falling apart.

title: Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close
review:
extremely long & incredibly childish. there were only a handful of good bits—otherwise this book seemed strangely immature (even though it's supposed to be from the POV of a child; the writing was just objectively horrendous) and I could not wait it to be over.

-----------------------------------

You cannot protect yourself from sadness without protecting yourself from happiness.

I'm so afraid of losing something I love that I refuse to love anything.

Life is scarier than death.

title: Nausea
review:
“I am. I am, I exist, I think, therefore I am; I am because I think, why do I think? I don't want to think any more, I am because I think that I don't want to be, I think that I . . . because . . . ugh!”

This book genuinely feels like nausea. A very fitting title. Written as a series of fragmented journal entries, it feels very stream-of-conscious and meta—so much to the point where I couldn't grasp anything that was going on. It's a chaotic mix of not just strange but also mundane events, all seen through the eyes of a not-very-mentally-stable narrator. 

While I didn't understand what was happening in this character's outside world, there were a few golden lines to be picked out of the narrator's remarkable internal self-reflections (very meta). I didn't enjoy it very much, but I think that might be the point—who is supposed to enjoy the feeling of nausea?

----------------------------------

Life has a meaning if we choose to give it one.

Once right has taken ahold of a man, exorcism cannot drive it out.

Perhaps there is nothing in the world I cling to as much as this feeling of adventure.

But everything changes when you tell about life; it's a change no one notices: the proof is that people talk about true stories. As if there could possibly be true stories; things happen one way and we tell about them in the opposite sense.

There is something I longed for more that all the rest - without realizing it properly. It wasn’t love, heaven forbid, nor glory, nor wealth. It was … anyway, I had imagined that at certain moments my life could take on a rare and precious quality.

I am beginning to believe that nothing can ever be proved. There are reasonable hypotheses that take facts into account: but I am all too aware that they come from me, that they are simply a way of unifying my knowledge.

title: Trust
review:
Money is a fantastic commodity. You can’t eat or wear money, but it represents all the food and clothes in the world. This is why it’s a fiction. 

Well-written, no doubt, and gives genius insights into life through the lens of ... finance, I guess. This book is purely about the finance world, and how finance controls the world—but it also makes broad statements on humanity and feminism through quite interesting plot twists. 

It is very fitting that this was published in the past few years, since money culture and materialism have just become so horrifically bad in modern society—especially with the rise of social media. I almost feel disgusted by the sheer amount of wealth this book butters the reader up with, since it feels so self-aggrandizing to read through these pages through the lens of such elite socialite characters.

Although Hernan Diaz is undeniably a good writer, very talented with words, I remember feeling lost at the purpose of this book after finishing it. It just seems to serve as entertainment to feed into our obsession with wealth and money as a society. Especially after living in LA for a bit, I feel like the subject matter of this book can be very dangerous—I have never felt less grounded in humble reality and instead feel constantly swept away by waves of materialistic fucking chaos.

I guess this book just fits relevantly into the terrible culture of greed and flashiness that our society continues to magnify through social media, so it won the nice (flashy, haha) Pulitzer Prize. It makes me anxious just thinking about this, which is why I didn't give this book a full five stars, but I guess I just need to face the inevitable reality of our greed-driven, money-loving society.

----------------------------------------------

The ideal conditions for business were never given. One had to create them.

Whenever we found ourselves walking along the waterfront, he would point at lower Manhattan, tracing the skyline with his finger while explaining that none of it really existed. 'A mirage,' he called it. 'Despite all those tall buildings—despite all that steel and concrete—Wall Street was,' he said, 'a fiction'. . . . 'Stock, shares, and all that garbage are just claims to future value. So if money is fiction, finance capital is the fiction of a fiction. That’s what all those criminals trade in: fictions.'

Fiction, harmless? Look at religion. Fiction harmless? Look at the oppressed masses content with their lot because they have embraced the lies imposed on them. History itself is just a fiction-a fiction with an army. And reality? Reality is a fiction with an unlimited budget. And how is reality funded? With yet another fiction: money. Money is at the core of it all. An illusion we've all agreed to support. We can differ on other matters, like creed or political affiliations, but we all agree on the fiction of money and that this abstraction represents concrete goods. 

Money is not one thing. It is, potentially, all things. And for this reason it is unrelated to all things.

The closer one is to the source of power, the quieter it gets.

Regardless of the circumstances, there is always room for individual action.

----------------------------------------------

What is this thing you call a soul? Is it like a kind of a glass? Before, we used to have a kind of glass that couldn't be broken. A truth so hard and clear it might as well have been made of glass. review:

title: The Martian
review:
I really did not get the hype behind this book. (insert crying face emoji here) I wanted to like it so desperately because of the gorgeous cover design and the fascinating subject matter (interplanetary exploration!?!?!!) ... but it really just seemed like an excuse for Andy Weir to show off how scientifically and mathematically accomplished he is. Half the book was just crunching numbers and matter-of-fact explanations. To my own alarm I did not find a single beautiful quote that I wanted to save (which has not happened for any other book I've read this entire year). I can see how people might like this book though, because it is just full of easy-to-read and relatable humor.

Maybe I am biased because working at JPL has proven to me how utterly unrealistic the events at JPL seemed ... it probably just hit a little too close to home. There is an alarming difference between a place's reputation and its reality, so I think I just hate how glorified and dramatized everything seemed in this book. 

Looking back I am trying desperately to find something that I learned or absorbed from the 10 hours I spent on this, but to be honest there's not much at all. This just felt like manufactured entertainment, not powerful art.

title: Elon Musk
review:
Optimism, pessimism, fuck that. We're going to make it happen.

So fascinating. Genius & insanity have to come as a package deal, I guess. Elon is definitely not lacking in the insanity arena, which is why I can see how a lot of people hate him. But this book also made me respect him for some of the acts of genius he has pulled off. It gives a fascinating behind-the-scenes look at what created that superhuman masochistic drive in him. Walter Isaacson is such an unparalleled biographer in the way he carefully pieces together details to really make a person 3D. This is a very objective view of Musk, in all his great glory but also his great shames. I just wonder why Isaacson had not waited longer to write this. We might need a Part 2 later. 

----------------------------------------------------------

Live dangerously, carefully.

I was used to South Africa where people will just rob you and kill you, so I slept on my backpack until I realized not everyone was a murderer.

I could go and buy one of the islands of the Bahamas and turn it into my personal fiefdom, but I am much more interested in trying to build and create a new company.

Separating the design of a product from its engineering was a recipe for dysfunction.

This is a land of adventurers. That spirit needed to be rekindled in America, he felt, and the best way to do that would be to embark on a mission to colonize Mars. To have a base on Mars would be incredibly difficult ... But it will be incredibly inspiring. And we must have inspiring things in the world.

Life cannot merely be about solving problems, he felt. It must also be about pursuing great dreams. That's what can get us up in the morning.

He never put much effort into sales and marketing, and instead believed that if you made a great product, the sales would follow.

We all make mistakes. What matters is if a person has a good feedback loop, can seek criticism from others, and can improve.

title: The 48 Laws of Power
review:
If the game of power is inescapable, better to be an artist than a denier or a bungler.

Highkey facts—but also somewhat of a monstrosity. Absolutely true though. Much better to learn how to play the game than to be played. 

Also, side note: this cover is a beautiful piece of design. Very genius. Conveys power to a T. 

Edit: side note pt. 2: all the laws in this book are (perhaps unexpectedly) incredibly applicable to artists. or anyone trying to make creative work to be seen by the world.

------------------------------------------------------

PREFACE

Any man who tries to be good is bound to come to ruin among the great number who are not good.

If the game of power is inescapable, better to be an artist than a denier or a bungler.

The value of a thing sometimes lies not in what one attains with it, but in what one pays for it - what it costs us. - Friedrich Nietzsche

Never discriminate as to who you study, and whom you trust. Never trust anyone completely. And study everyone.

LAW 1: NEVER OUTSHINE THE MASTER

“Never take your position for granted and never let any favors you receive go to your head.”

LAW 2: NEVER PUT TOO MUCH TRUST IN FRIENDS, LEARN HOW TO USE ENEMIES

All working situations require a kind of distance between people. The key to power, then, is the ability to judge who is best able to further your interests in all situations. Keep friends for friendship, but work with the skilled and competent.”

“A person who has something to prove will move mountains for you.”

“Without a worthy opponent, a man or group cannot grow stronger.”

LAW 5: SO MUCH DEPENDS ON REPUTATION. GUARD IT WITH YOUR LIFE

“Reputation is the cornerstone of power. Through reputation alone you can intimidate and win; once it slips, however, you are vulnerable, and will be attacked on all sides. Make your reputation unassailable.”

LAW 6: COURT ATTENTION AT ALL COST

“Better to create something ugly and disturbing, [Picasso] believed, than to let viewers grow too familiar with his work. Understand: People feel superior to the person whose actions they can predict.”

“People are enthralled by mystery; because it invites constant interpretation, they never tire of it. The mysterious cannot be grasped. And what cannot be seized and consumed creates power.”

LAW 11: LEARN TO KEEP PEOPLE DEPENDENT ON YOU

“To maintain your independence you must always be needed and wanted. The more you are relied on, the more freedom you have.”

LAW 12: USE SELECTIVE HONESTY AND GENEROSITY TO DISARM YOUR VICTIM

“Learn to give before you take. It softens the ground, takes the bite out of a future request.”

LAW 13: WHEN ASKING FOR HELP, APPEAL TO PEOPLE'S SELF-INTEREST, NEVER TO THEIR MERCY OR GRATITUDE 

“Self-interest is the lever that will move people.”

LAW 16: USE ABSENCE TO INCREASE RESPECT AND HONOR

“Create value through scarcity.”

LAW 20: DO NOT COMMIT TO ANYONE

“If you allow people to feel they possess you to any degree, you lose all power over them. By not committing your affections, they will only try harder to win you over.”

LAW 22: USE THE SURRENDER TACTIC: TRANSFORM WEAKNESS INTO POWER

“This is the essence of the surrender tactic: Inwardly you stay firm, but outwardly you bend.”

LAW 23: CONCENTRATE YOUR FORCES

“As Schopenhauer wrote, 'Intellect is a magnitude of intensity, not a magnitude of extensity.'

LAW 24: PLAY THE PERFECT COURTIER

“Be Frugal in Asking Those Above You for Favors. Most important: Do not ask for favors on another person's behalf, least of all a friend's.”

Be Self-observant. You must be the mirror, training your mind to try to see yourself as others see you.”

LAW 34: BE ROYAL IN YOUR OWN FASHION: ACT LIKE A KING TO BE TREATED LIKE ONE

It is within your power to set your own price. 

LAW 35: MASTER THE ART OF TIMING

“Time is an artificial concept that we ourselves have created to make the limitlessness of eternity and the universe more bearable, more human.”

LAW 37: CREATE COMPELLING SPECTACLES

“The symbol contains untold power. The visual has come to dominate the others, and is the sense we most depend on and trust. As Gracian said, “The truth is generally seen, rarely heard.”

“Never neglect the way you arrange things visually. The visual contains great emotional power.”

LAW 38: THINK AS YOU LIKE BUT BEHAVE LIKE OTHERS

“In society, outward appearances are what matter.”

LAW 40: DESPISE THE FREE LUNCH

“What has worth is worth paying for. There is no cutting corners with excellence.”

LAW 43: WORK ON THE HEARTS AND MINDS OF OTHERS

“The quickest way to secure people's minds is by demonstrating, as simply as possible, how an action will benefit them. The cause seduces but the self-interest secures the deal.”

LAW 46: NEVER APPEAR TOO PERFECT

“Appearing better than others is always dangerous, but most dangerous of all is to appear to have no faults or weaknesses. Envy creates silent enemies.

“The master of power understands that the appearance of superiority over others is inconsequential next to the reality of it.”

LAW 47: DO NOT GO PAST THE MARK YOU AIMED FOR; IN VICTORY, LEARN WHEN TO STOP

“As they say in riding school, you have to be able to control yourself before you can control the horse.”

When you have won a victory, tighten the strings of your helmet.

LAW 48: ASSUME FORMLESSNESS

“By taking a shape, by having a visible plan, you open yourself to attack. Instead of taking a form for your enemy to grasp, keep yourself adaptable and on the move. Accept the fact that nothing is certain and no law is fixed. The best way to protect yourself is to be as fluid and formless as water; never bet on stability or lasting order. Everything changes.”
