title: Mastery
review:
“One can have no smaller or greater mastery than mastery of oneself. — LEONARDO DA VINCI

Not a perfect book by any means but the meat of this book is so critical to a meaningful life that it had to join the 5-star shelf for me. Greene literally felt like a cult leader preaching to me because I was entranced. He makes so many astute and resoundingly true observations about past individuals' journeys to mastery—social/behavioral psychology at its absolute finest, though not quite its most scientific. This book will light a fire under you to get your ass up and really live your life.

-------------------------------------------------------------

In every work of genius we recognize our own rejected thoughts. - Ralph Waldo Emerson

“Conforming to social norms, you will listen more to others than to your own voice. Most often you deviate because of the lure of money, of more immediate prospects of prosperity. Because this does not comply with something deep within you, your interest will lag and eventually the money will not come so easily. Not seeing clearly ahead of you, you will end up in a dead-end career. Even if your material needs are met, you will feel an emptiness inside that you will need to fill with any kind of belief system, drugs, or diversions. You may grow frustrated and depressed, never realizing that the source of it is your alienation from your own creative potential. In the end, the money and success that truly last come not to those who focus on such things as goals, but rather to those who focus on mastery and fulfilling their Life’s Task.”

People get the mind and the quality of brain they deserve through their actions in life. Despite the popularity of genetic explanations for our behavior, scientists are demonstrating the degree to which the brain is actually quite plastic—how our thoughts determine our mental landscape.

“People who are passive create a mental landscape that is rather barren. Because of their limited experiences and action, all kinds of connections in the brain die off from lack of use.

Pushing against the passive trend of these times, you must work to see how far you can extend control of your circumstances and create the kind of mind you desire—not through drugs but through action.”

“Everything that happens to you is a form of instruction if you pay attention.”

“In moving toward mastery, you are bringing your mind closer to reality and to life itself. Anything that is alive is in a continual state of change and movement. The creativity that you gain in learning a skill so deeply must be constantly refreshed, as you keep forcing your mind back to a state of openness. The moment that you rest, thinking that you have attained the level you desire, a part of your mind enters a phase of decay. This is a power and intelligence that must be continually renewed or it will die.”

CHAPTER 1

“Too often we make a separation in our lives—there is work and there is life outside work, where we find real pleasure and fulfillment. Work is often seen as a means for making money so we can enjoy that second life that we lead. Even if we derive some satisfaction from our careers we still tend to compartmentalize our lives in this way. This is a depressing attitude, because in the end we spend a substantial part of our waking life at work. If we experience this time as something to get through on the way to real pleasure, then our hours at work represent a tragic waste of the short time we have to live. Instead you want to see your work as something more inspiring, as part of your vocation.”

“What we lack most in the modern world is a sense of a larger purpose to our lives. In the past, it was organized religion that often supplied this. But most of us now live in a secularized world. We human animals are unique—we must build our own world. We do not simply react to events out of biological scripting. But without a sense of direction provided to us, we tend to flounder. We don’t how to fill up and structure our time. There seems to be no defining purpose to our lives. We are perhaps not conscious of this emptiness, but it infects us in all kinds of ways. Feeling that we are called to accomplish something is the most positive way for us to supply this sense of purpose and direction. It is a religious-like quest for each of us.”

“Our times might emphasize equality, which we then mistake for the need for everyone to be the same, but what we really mean by this is the equal chance for people to express their differences, to let a thousand flowers bloom.”

“Remember: your Life’s Task is a living, breathing organism. The moment you rigidly follow a plan set in your youth, you lock yourself into a position, and the times will ruthlessly pass you by.”

CHAPTER 2

“The pain is a kind of challenge your mind presents—will you learn how to focus and move past the boredom, or like a child will you succumb to the need for immediate pleasure and distraction? Much as with physical exercise, you can even get a kind of perverse pleasure out of this pain, knowing the benefits it will bring you. Throughout your life you will encounter tedious situations, and you must cultivate the ability to handle them with discipline.”

“Trying something over and over again grounds you in reality, making you deeply aware of your inadequacies and of what you can accomplish with more work and effort.”

“Learning any kind of skill deeply prepares you for mastery. The sensation of flow and of being a part of the instrument is a precursor to the great pleasures that mastery can bring. In essence, when you practice and develop any skill you transform yourself in the process. You develop emotionally. Your sense of pleasure becomes redefined. What offers immediate pleasure comes to seem like a distraction, an empty entertainment to help pass the time. Real pleasure comes from overcoming challenges, feeling confidence in your abilities, gaining fluency in skills, and experiencing the power this brings.”

“As you gain in skill and confidence, you must make the move to a more active mode of experimentation. Often you must force yourself to initiate such actions or experiments before you think you are ready.”

“The process of learning skills, no matter how virtual, remains the same. In the future, the great division will be between those who have trained themselves to handle these complexities and those who are overwhelmed by them—those who can acquire skills and discipline their minds and those who are irrevocably distracted by all the media around them and can never focus enough to learn.”

“The paradox is that the mind is essentially free. It can travel anywhere, across time and space. If she kept it confined to her narrow circumstances, it would be her own fault.”

“Revert to a feeling of inferiority. If we feel like we know something, our minds close off to other possibilities. We see reflections of the truth we have already assumed. This sense of inferiority gives us a hunger to learn.”

“Unlike other animals, we humans retain what is known as neoteny—mental and physical traits of immaturity—well into our adult years. We have the remarkable capability of returning to a childlike spirit. Children's minds are completely open; they pay greater attention. This is why they can learn so quickly and so deeply.

CHAPTER 3

“But true Zen never stops, never congeals into such truths. That is why everyone must constantly be pushed to the abyss, starting over and feeling their utter worthlessness as a student. Without suffering and doubts, the mind will come to rest on clichés and stay there, until the spirit dies as well. Not even enlightenment is enough. You must continually start over and challenge yourself.”

“Developing discipline through challenging situations and perhaps suffering along the way are no longer values that are promoted in our culture. [But] Masters are those who by nature have suffered to get to where they are. ”

CHAPTER 4

“Social intelligence is the ability to see people in the most realistic light possible. By moving past our usual self-absorption, we can learn to focus deeply on others, reading their behavior in the moment, seeing what motivates them, and discerning any possible manipulative tendencies. Success attained without this intelligence is not true mastery, and will not last.”

“The most effective attitude to adopt is one of supreme acceptance. You are an observer of the human comedy, and by being as tolerant as possible, you gain a much greater ability to understand people and to influence their behavior when necessary.”

“People will say all kinds of things about their motives and intentions; they are used to dressing things up with words. Their actions, however, say much more about their character, about what is going on underneath the surface.”

“You will encounter thousands of various individuals in your life, and the ability to see them as they are will prove invaluable. Keep in mind, however, that people are in a state of continual flux. You must not let your ideas about them harden into a set impression.”

“You must be particularly careful to never make people feel stupid in your presence. Intelligence is the most sensitive trigger point for envy. It is always wise to occasionally reveal your own insecurities, which will humanize you in other people’s eyes. Self-deprecating humor will work wonders as well.”

“When it is time to ask for a favor or help, you must think first of appealing to people’s self-interest in some way.”

See yourself as others see you.

CHAPTER 5

“If we think deeply about our childhood, not just about our memories of it but how it actually felt, we realize how differently we experienced the world back then. Our minds were completely open, and we entertained all kinds of surprising, original ideas. Things that we now take for granted, things as simple as the night sky or our reflection in a mirror, often caused us to wonder. Not yet having commanded language, we thought in ways that were preverbal—in images and sensations. This mind looked at the world more directly—not through words and received ideas. It was flexible and receptive to new information.”

“Masters and those who display a high level of creative energy are simply people who manage to retain a sizeable portion of their childhood spirit despite the pressures and demands of adulthood. They are able to ask the kinds of simple questions that most people pass over, but they have the rigor and discipline to follow their investigations all the way to the end. They retain a childlike excitement about their field and a playful approach, all of which makes the hours of hard work alive and pleasurable. Like children, they are capable of thinking beyond words—visually, spatially, intuitively—and have greater access to preverbal and unconscious forms of mental activity, all of which can account for their surprising ideas and creations.”

“Think of everything in nature, or in the world, as a kind of hologram—the smallest part reflecting something essential about the whole. Immersing yourself in details will combat the generalizing tendencies of the brain and bring you closer to reality.”

 “Truly creative people in all fields can temporarily suspend their ego and simply experience what they are seeing, without the need to assert a judgment, for as long as possible. They are more than ready to find their most cherished opinions contradicted by reality.”

PART E. REVERT TO PRIMAL FORMS OF INTELLIGENCE — VISUAL, NOT LANGUAGE, THINKING

“To Leonardo da Vinci, drawing and thinking were synonymous. The hand-brain connection is something deeply wired within us; when we attempt to sketch something we must observe it closely, gaining a feel through our fingers of how to bring it to life. Such practice can help you think in visual terms and free your mind from its constant verbalizations.”

“Creative people do not simply think in words, but use all of their senses, their entire bodies in the process. They find sense cues that stimulate their thoughts on many levels. What this means is that they are more open to alternative ways of thinking, creating, and sensing the world. They allow themselves a broader range of sense experience. You must expand as well your notion of thinking and creativity beyond the confines of words and intellectualizations. Stimulating your brain and senses from all directions will help unlock your natural creativity and help revive your original mind.”

“After we pass through a rigorous apprenticeship and begin to flex our creative muscles, we cannot help but feel satisfaction in what we have learned and how far we have progressed. We naturally begin to take for granted certain ideas we have learned and developed. Fight this downhill tendency as much as you can by upholding the value of active wonder. Constantly remind yourself of how little you truly know, and of how mysterious the world remains.”

“The best way to neutralize our natural impatience is to cultivate a kind of pleasure in pain—like an athlete, you come to enjoy rigorous practice, pushing past your limits, and resisting the easy way out.”

“Sometimes greater danger comes from success and praise than from criticism. If we learn to handle criticism well, it can strengthen us and help us become aware of flaws in our work. Praise generally does harm. Ever so slowly, the emphasis shifts from the joy of the creative process to the love of attention and to our ever-inflating ego. Without realizing it, we alter and shape our work to attract the praise that we crave. What must ultimately motivate you is the work itself and the process.

“We are all in search of feeling more connected to reality. We indulge in drugs or alcohol, or engage in dangerous sports or risky behavior, just to wake ourselves up from the sleep of our daily existence and feel a heightened sense of connection to reality. In the end, however, the most satisfying and powerful way to feel this connection is through creative activity. Engaged in the creative process we feel more alive than ever, because we are making something and not merely consuming, Masters of the small reality we create.”

“There is nothing that becomes repetitive and boring more quickly than free expression that is not rooted in reality and discipline.”

“Oddly enough, what really makes successful entrepreneurs is not the nature of their idea, or the university they went to, but their actual character—their willingness to adapt their idea and take advantage of possibilities they had not first imagined. This is precisely the trait—fluidity of mind—that Graham had identified in himself and in other inventors. The other essential character trait was supreme tenacity.”

CHAPTER 6

“Keep reminding yourself of the way things are connected, of their relatedness. All things are implicated in one another and in sympathy with each other. This event is the consequence of some other one. Things push and pull on each other, and breathe together, and are one.” - Marcus Aurelius

“Mastery is not a function of genius or talent. It is a function of time and intense focus applied to a particular field of knowledge.”

“Soon, thinking and drawing became fused in his mind. Through drawing things in the world around him, he came to understand them.”

“But anything that is peculiar to our makeup is precisely what we must pay the deepest attention to and lean on in our rise to mastery. Mastery is like swimming—it is too difficult to move forward when we are creating our own resistance or swimming against the current. Know your strengths and move with them.”

title: The Overstory
review:
Real joy consists of knowing that human wisdom counts less than the shimmer of beaches in a breeze.

There is no knowing for a fact. The only dependable things are humility and looking. 

There are no individuals in a forest, no separable events. 

Do you know what actuarial science is? It's the science of replacing an entire human life with its cash value.

The best arguments in the world won't change a person's mind. The only thing that can do that is a good story.

Spectacular showstopping beautiful writing. You can tell that Powers really milked the experience of crafting this book and that it meant a lot to him. It's a very nice forest to escape into—it's nice to believe in the power of the underdog and of secret, quiet growth. The weaving-together of the separate storylines was kind of a slog to get through though, and the book could have done with pruning out some of its branching, but it was still a good and memorable experience. Very creative and truthful to life.

title: In the Dream House
review:
Gushing, beautiful technique. Very good writing. Makes you very uncomfortable, but maybe that's the whole point. Maybe the reason I'm struggling to give this five stars is because it made me very, very uncomfortable. But I can resonate with many things. Especially the burning, self-affirming need to confirm that suffering happened, even if it didn't leave a physical mark. This book is all a mental game, like battling with a thick, formless sludge. Very dangerous, and, I hate to admit, powerful.

Part 4 - Dream House as a Stopgap Measure

'The trouble with letting people see you at your worst isn't that they'll remember; it's that you'll remember.' - Sarah Manguso

What is the value of proof? What does it mean for something to be true? If a tree falls in the woods and pins a wood thrush to the earth, and she shrieks and shrieks but no one hears her, did she make a sound? Did she suffer? Who's to say?

title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
review:
“How did Homo sapiens manage to cross this critical threshold, eventually founding cities comprising tens of thousands of inhabitants and empires ruling hundreds of millions? The secret was probably the appearance of fiction. Large numbers of strangers can cooperate successfully by believing in common myths. Any large-scale human cooperation – whether a modern state, a medieval church, an ancient city or an archaic tribe – is rooted in common myths that exist only in people's collective imagination.”

Fascinating survey of all sorts of things related to the nature of being human. History and psychology stripped out of stiff school textbooks into interesting, 3-dimensional stories. I liked the conversational, never-overbearing tone; Harari completely upends the commonly accepted views ingrained deep within Western/globalized societies and yet makes you think you did all the hard work and thinking by yourself. This is a very intelligent man with the acute ability to observe things as they are, not as we make them up to be in our heads. It's just funny to realize that the entire systems of our societies, our nations, our empires—are all built upon myths. It all comes down to stories. This book has a few nice snippets of many good ones. 

----------------------------------
CH 1: AN ANIMAL OF NO SIGNIFICANCE 

“Most mammals emerge from the womb like glazed earthenware emerging from a kiln – any attempt at remoulding will scratch or break them. Humans emerge from the womb like molten glass from a furnace. They can be spun, stretched and shaped with a surprising degree of freedom”

CH 2: THE TREE OF KNOWLEDGE

“How did Homo sapiens manage to cross this critical threshold, eventually founding cities comprising tens of thousands of inhabitants and empires ruling hundreds of millions? The secret was probably the appearance of fiction. Large numbers of strangers can cooperate successfully by believing in common myths.”

“Any large-scale human cooperation – whether a modern state, a medieval church, an ancient city or an archaic tribe – is rooted in common myths that exist only in people's collective imagination.”

CH 8: THERE IS NO JUSTICE IN HISTORY

“'Biology enables, Culture forbids.’ Biology is willing to tolerate a very wide spectrum of possibilities. It’s culture that obliges people to realize some possibilities while forbidding others.”

CH 9: THE ARROW OF HISTORY

“Consistency is the playground of dull minds.”

CH 10: THE SCENT OF MONEY

“Money is more open-minded than language, state laws, cultural codes, religious beliefs and social habits. Money is the only trust system created by humans that can bridge almost any cultural gap, and that does not discriminate on the basis of religion, gender, race, age or sexual orientation.”

CH 12: THE LAW OF RELIGION

“Humans have a wonderful capacity to believe in contradictions.”

“If you experience sadness without craving that the sadness go away, you continue to feel sadness but you do not suffer from it. There can actually be richness in the sadness. If you experience joy without craving that the joy linger and intensify, you continue to feel joy without losing your peace of mind.”

“A person who does not crave cannot suffer.”

CH 16: THE CAPITALIST CREED

“What enables banks – and the entire economy – to survive and flourish is our trust in the future. This trust is the sole backing for most of the money in the world. The fact is, it’s not a deception, but rather a tribute to the amazing abilities of the human imagination.”

“Credit enables us to build the present at the expense of the future. It’s founded on the assumption that our future resources are sure to be far more abundant than our present resources. A host of new and wonderful opportunities open up if we can build things in the present using future income.”

CH 19: AND THEY LIVED HAPPILY EVER AFTER

“Nothing in the comfortable lives of the urban middle class can approach the wild excitement and sheer joy experienced by a forager band on a successful mammoth hunt. Every new invention just puts another mile between us and the Garden of Eden.”

“One interesting conclusion is that money does indeed bring happiness. But only up to a point, and beyond that point it has little significance.”

“Family and community seem to have more impact on our happiness than money and health. People with strong families who live in tight-knit and supportive communities are significantly happier than people whose families are dysfunctional and who have never found (or never sought) a community to be part of.”

“But the most important finding of all is that happiness does not really depend on objective conditions of either wealth, health or even community. Rather, it depends on the correlation between objective conditions and subjective expectations.”

“Prophets, poets and philosophers realised thousands of years ago that being satisfied with what you already have is far more important than getting more of what you want. Still, it’s nice when modern research – bolstered by lots of numbers and charts – reaches the same conclusions the ancients did.”

“As Nietzsche put it, if you have a why to live, you can bear almost any how.”

“A meaningful life can be extremely satisfying even in the midst of hardship, whereas a meaningless life is a terrible ordeal no matter how comfortable it is.”

“Is there anything more dangerous than dissatisfied and irresponsible gods who don’t know what they want?”

title: Let My People Go Surfing: The Education of a Reluctant Businessman
review: Very principled, intrepid, and inspiring person. The writing itself is not as spectacular as Phil Knight's Shoe Dog or some other memoirs, but I guess there's a reason this man became (even if accidentally) a CEO and not a writer. Still a very good read though, although I don't remember much from it looking back two months later.

title: Uncle Vanya
review:
Haha really only picked up this book/play because it's featured in the movie Drive My Car and because it's short. But it hits so many true true points. At first I was even doubting to myself how a little obscure play like this could be a major plot point in a multimillion dollar movie, but yeah, confirmed—Chekhov is a master of literature and thought and life. Hope really is the pillar of the world.

ACT I:

Man is endowed with reason and the power to create, so that he may increase that which has been given him, but until now he has not created, but demolished.

ACT II:

When real life is wanting one must create an illusion. It is better than nothing.

An idle life can never be a pure one.

You must not look so at people. It is not becoming to you. You must trust people, or life become impossible.

ACT IV:

Don't pay the least attention to them; we are all dependents on God. You and Sonia and all of us. Every one must work, no one can sit idle.

Give it up, Uncle Vanya! My misfortune is perhaps even greater than yours, but I am not plunged in despair. I endure my sorrow, and shall endure it until my life comes to a natural end. You must endure yours, too.

What can we do? We must live our lives.

Ah, then dear, dear Uncle, we shall see that bright and beautiful life; we shall rejoice and look back upon our sorrow here; a tender smile—and—we shall rest.

title: Notes from Underground
review:
Which is better, cheap happiness or exalted sufferings?

Hard to get through. But interesting that this book unearths all the buried thoughts that convention usually encourages us to hide away. By making the narrator an insufferable hag, Dostoevsky trojan-horses ugly truths that any agreeable narrator could never touch on. Sadly, this book is not cheap happiness but instead quite exalted and onerous suffering.

------------------------------------------------

I swear, gentlemen, that to be too conscious is an illness. A real thorough-going illness. 

I am firmly persuaded that a great deal of consciousness, every sort of consciousness, in fact, is a disease.

But in despair there are the most intense enjoyments.

Man is stupid, you know, phenomenally stupid.

May it not be that he loves chaos and destruction? Because he is instinctively afraid of attaining his object and completing the edifice he is constructing. Who knows, perhaps he only loves that edifice from a distance and is by no means in love with it at close quarters. 

Perhaps the only goal on earth to which mankind is striving lies in this incessant process of attaining. In other words, in life itself. And not in the thing to be attained. Which must always be expressed as a formula, as positive as twice two makes four. And such positiveness is not life, gentlemen, but is the beginning of death.

Doesn't man, perhaps, love something besides well-being? Perhaps he's just as fond of suffering. Perhaps suffering is just as great a benefit to him as well-being.

Man is sometimes extraordinarily, passionately in love with suffering and that's a fact.

Which is better, cheap happiness or exalted sufferings?

title: The Beautiful and Damned
review:
Things are sweeter when they're lost. I know, because once I wanted something and got it ... And when I got it, it turned to dust in my hands.

Brilliant. Fitzgerald is a genius, someone who has unlocked many secrets in life and writing. The writing is beautiful, unique, and fresh but—maybe this book was too depressing for me to let myself be immersed thoroughly. Dragged on for quite a bit in decadence and sickeningly rich stupidity. Probably not a book to look toward as a great example of life—so not really the type of book that I've been hoping for lately.

BOOK ONE  I. ANTHONY PATCH

 'Art isn't meaningless.'
'It is in itself. It isn't in that it tries to make life less so.'
 'On the contrary, I'd feel that it being a meaningless world, why write? The very attempt to give it purpose is purposeless.' 
'Well, even admitting all that, be a decent pragmatist and grant a poor man the instinct to live.'

BOOK TWO I. THE RADIANT HOUR

There's no beauty without poignancy, and there's no poignancy without the feeling that it's going—men, names, books, houses—bound for dust. Mortal.

BOOK TWO II. SYMPOSIUM

There's only one lesson to be learned from life anyway ... That there's no lesson to be learned from life.

BOOK THREE I. A MATTER OF CIVILIZATION

Things are sweeter when they're lost. I know, because once I wanted something and got it ... And when I got it, it turned to dust in my hands.

BOOK THREE II. A MATTER OF AESTHETICS

Perhaps, they think that in proclaiming the evil of living, they somehow salvage their own worth from the ruin. But they don't.
Beauty is only to be admired, only to be loved.

BOOK THREE III. NO MATTER!

There was nothing, it seemed, that grew stale so soon as pleasure.

title: Benjamin Franklin: An American Life
review:
The man who lives by his labor is at least free.

Extraordinarily boring. Told in fact-by-fact-history-textbook style. Franklin does not at all come alive like Jobs did in Isaacson's writing. Probably because Franklin died a few hundred years ago (and Isaacson never talked to him live), but in this book there's only a sense of Franklin as a stiff 2D cardboard cutout rather than a real person. Franklin's genius and industriousness is still admirable, but I found it strange how Isaacson tried to cover up his blatant disloyalty to his wife. Heavily biased narration for sure, but there were still a few gems of wisdom. 

Favorite Franklin quotes:

CH 2: PILGRIM'S PROGRESS

Industry and frugality are the means of procuring wealth and thereby securing virtue.

CH 3: JOURNEYMAN

So convenient a thing it is to be a reasonable creature, since it enables one to find or make a reason for everything one has a mind to do.

People are more likely to admire your work if you are able to keep them from feeling jealous of you.

Since pain, naturally and infallibly, produces a pleasure in proportion to it, every individual creature must, in any state of life, have an equal quantity of each.

CH 4: PRINTER

Knowledge was obtained rather by the use of the ear than of the tongue.

Such is the vanity of mankind that minding what others say is a much surer way of pleasing them than talking well ourselves.

Early to bed, and early to rise, makes a man healthy, wealthy, and wise.

CH 5: PUBLIC CITIZEN

People will eventually give you the credit if you don't try to claim it at the time. The present little sacrifice of your vanity will eventually be amply repaid.

I would rather have it said 'He lived usefully' than 'He died rich.'

CH 8: TROUBLED WATERS

The man who lives by his labor is at least free.

CH 15: PEACEMAKER

In America, people do not inquire of a stranger 'What is he?' but 'What can he do?

Industry and constant employment are great preservatives of moral and virtue.

title: First Person Singular: Stories
review:
Loving someone is like having a mental illness that's not covered by health insurance.

Classic Murakami. Classic stories that make you feel like the only person in the world. Maybe a three-star book on the Murakami scale, but four stars in general among the wider range of literature. Not mediocre at all (except for maybe like one story).

------------------------------------------------

Cream

There's nothing worth getting in this world that you can get easily.

The cream of the cream. It means the best of the best. The most important essence of life. That's the créme de la créme.

(I still remember this story clearly after first reading it 5 years ago—this was the cream of all his short stories for me so far.)

On a Stone Pillow

Loving someone is like having a mental illness that's not covered by health insurance.

Carnaval

This might sound like a banal opinion, but the world can turn upside down depending on the way we look at it. 

The way a ray of sunshine falls on something can change shadow to light, or light to shadow. A positive becomes a negative, a negative a positive.

Beneath an evil spirit mask lies the natural face of an angel. Beneath an angel's mask lies the face of an evil spirit. It's impossible to have just one or the other. That's who we are.

Happiness is always a relative thing, don't you think?

The Yakult Swallows Poetry Collection

It's true that life brings us far more defeats than victories. And real life wisdom arises not so much from knowing how we might beat someone as from learning how to accept defeat with grace.

Whether the team wins or loses, I loved the time spent there most of all. Of course, winning is much better than losing. But winning or losing doesn't affect the weight and value of the time. It's the same time either way. A minute is a minute, an hour is an hour. We need to cherish it. We need to deftly reconcile ourselves with time and leave behind as many precious memories as we can. That's what's the most valuable.

title: The Art of War
review: Lots of great tips for fighting war and just a few great ones for the art of life.

title: Outline
review:
“As it happened, I was no longer interested in literature as a form of snobbery or even self-definition. I had no desire to prove that one book was better than another; in fact, if I read something I admired, I found myself increasingly disinclined to mention it at all. What I knew personally to be true had come to seem unrelated to the process of persuading others. I did not, any longer, want to persuade anyone of anything.”

I am somewhat confused. This book is certainly an outline—since it is not quite a coherent story. It has just the most beautifully rendered snippets and sketches of life—like a fascinating little sketchbook, but not a completed refined painting. It's still very interesting to peer into Cusk's mind like that though; she has brilliant writing technique & paints vivid, advanced pictures. Perhaps I was just not in the right headspace to fully receive her work. Outline was full of cute little vignettes, yet just not quite the heart-gripping story I have been finding myself wanting recently.

------------------------------------------------

I always expected that at some point they would realize the distress was unnecessary and they would choose to avoid it, but they never did. The memory of suffering had no effect whatever on what they elected to do. On the contrary, it compelled them to repeat it. For the suffering was the magic that caused the object to come back and allowed the delight in dropping it to become possible again.

“As it happened, I was no longer interested in literature as a form of snobbery or even self-definition. I had no desire to prove that one book was better than another; in fact, if I read something I admired, I found myself increasingly disinclined to mention it at all. What I knew personally to be true had come to seem unrelated to the process of persuading others. I did not, any longer, want to persuade anyone of anything.”

It made you a better writer, did it not? Not having an identity to fall back on. You saw the world with less troubled eyes.

I suppose it's a bit like marriage. You build a whole structure on a period of intensity that's never repeated. It's the basis of your faith, and you sometimes doubt it, but you never renounce it because too much of your life stands on that ground. 

What I miss is the discipline itself. In a way I don't care what I write. I just want that feeling of being in sync again, body and mind.

That's writing for you. When you make space for passion, it doesn't turn up.

Above the world, objects didn't count for so much. Differences were less apparent.

But what other people thought was no longer of any help to me. Those thoughts only existed within certain structures. And I had definitively left those structures. 

For people are at their least aware of others when demonstrating their own power over them. 

But all the same, it was brought home to me how much of what was beautiful in their lives was a result of a shared vision of things that, strictly speaking, could not have been said to exist.

The human capacity for self-delusion is apparently infinite.

And how can you even know you have taken something for granted until it is no longer there? 

'And so I learned,' he said, 'that it is impossible to improve things. And that good people are just as responsible for it as bad. And that improvement itself is perhaps a mere personal fantasy.'

'It was important,' my neighbor said, 'to remember to enjoy yourself along the way.'

title: The Song of Achilles
review:
Amazing story, really just sucks you in. 

He said what he meant. Some people might have mistaken this for simplicity, but is it not a sort of genius to gut always to the heart?

Very spectacular writing, even if it almost reads like a Wattpad fan fic at some points. Highly recommend the audiobook experience.

title: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow
review:
“What is a game? Marx said. It's tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow. It's the possibility of infinite rebirth, infinite redemption. The idea that if you keep playing, you could win. No loss is permanent, because nothing is permanent, ever.”

Exquisite novel, but maybe I wasn't in the right headspace to absorb it right now. Probably because of a too-recent visit to Cambridge, to the exact setting of this novel, that carried too many personal meanings for my own story that I could not ignore while trying to experience these characters' stories. Excellently crafted book, very well-chosen themes and motifs. Feels very real and full of heart, lots of moments I could connect to my own universe and play through.

Also finished this entire book within two days, which probably shows how natural, compelling, and beautiful a story it is.

-----------------------------------------

A truly magnificent thing about the way the brain was coded, Sam thought, was that it could say 'Excuse me' while meaning 'Screw you.'

You're incredibly gifted son, but it is worth noting that to be good at something is not quite the same as loving it.

To allow yourself to play with another person is no small risk. It means allowing yourself to be open, to be exposed, to be hurt.

I forget how young you are. You're still at the age where you mistake your friends and your colleagues for family.

The world had always looked painfully beautiful to him when he was sick. It was only when he was alone, and he couldn't participate in the business of living, that he tended to notice how lovely being alive was.

“What is a game? Marx said. It's tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow. It's the possibility of infinite rebirth, infinite redemption. The idea that if you keep playing, you could win. No loss is permanent, because nothing is permanent, ever.”

Art doesn't typically get made by happy people.

title: Steve Jobs
review:
so creative, so crazy inspiring. take a shot every time you read the intersection of art and technology and you might be dead. Jobs' reality distortion field was a veryyy intriguing concept too. really hit home how marketing, brand identity, and external appearance (e.g. design) was just as important, if not more important, than the products themselves.

wish I had had time to go back to my bookmarks and note down all the interesting quotes before my library loan expired :(

--------------------------------

Remembering you are going to die is the best way I know to avoid the trap of thinking you have something to lose. You are already naked. There is no reason not to follow your heart.

title: The Secret History
review:
Beauty is terror. Whatever we call beautiful, we quiver before it.

Very very very well written. Beautiful in all senses—in a harsh, terrifying, and hedonistic way. Unfortunately I made the mistake of checking out the audiobook narrated by the author herself; although she is clearly brilliant, so so intelligent, and she knows exactly how it was intended to be read (since she wrote it), there is almost too much thinking behind the way she reads. She does not fully lose herself to the words in the way that hotheaded passionate actors can (like David Pittu for her other audiobook); there's a highly academic and intellectual stiffness behind it all, which makes sense because only a mind like that could write a book like this. 

Listening to this book was a very vulnerable/depressing experience for me as its events carried on ... I definitely enjoyed The Goldfinch more but these characters certainly set an example for what to avoid in life. Though there are probably things that can be learned from them as well.

At the very core Donna Tartt is someone who appreciates beauty. And it was a nice reminder for me to do that as well—clouds and arching trees and books and blue skies ... a nice reminder to stay grateful ... so that one might escape these peoples' careless, indulgent, and depressing fates.

After all, the appeal to stop being yourself, even for a little while, is very great. To escape the cognitive mode of experience. To transcend the accident of one's moment of being. 

People don't pay attention to 90% of what they see.

Nihil sub sole novum. Any action, in the fullness of time, sinks to nothingness.

It was the most important night of my life. It enabled me to do what I've always wanted to do most ... To live without thinking.

There is nothing wrong with the love of beauty. But beauty, unless she is wed to something more meaningful, is always superficial.

title: Sea of Tranquility
review:
Fascinating & creative. Also has one of the most beautiful & enticing book covers, which has definitely lived in my head rent-free ever since I first saw it last year. 

A very thought-provoking, very un-real reflection of reality. With a very fitting title. 

If there's pleasure in action, there's peace in stillness. 

It's extraordinary; I hope I never get used to it.

It's hard to know what we know sometimes, isn't it.

title: Novelist as a Vocation
review:
Just Murakami Murakami-ing. Such a Murakami book, even though it doesn't have talking cats or falling fish and instead tells the true, decidedly non-surreal story of the author's own life. But in a way, it's still surreal. Still written, as always, in that iconic & refreshing Murakami voice.

To reach the source, you have to swim against the current. Only trash swims downstream.

Think how many, far too many, things we pick up in the course of living. 

It is my belief that a rich, spontaneous joy lies at the root of all creative expression.

This is purely my opinion, but if you want to express yourself as freely as you can, it's probably best not to start out by asking 'What am I seeking?' Rather, it's better to ask: 'Who would I be if I weren't seeking anything?'

Something truly important is not that easy to forget once you've entrusted it to your memory.

Imagination is memory. - James Joyce

What we call the imagination consists of fragments of memory that lack any clear connection with one another. 

The key component is not the quality of the materials. What's needed is magic. If that magic is present, the most basic daily matters and the plainest language can be turned into a device of surprising sophistication. 

You can realize the glorious feeling of practicing magic. For writing a novel is, in the end, forging a link with people on other planets.

I write a little every day, without hope, without despair.”― Isak Dinesen

But if you are able to view where you are standing from other perspectives—to put it another way, if you can reflect and entrust your existence to some other system—the world will grow more 3-dimensional, more supple. And I believe that, as long as we live in this world, that kind of agile stance is extremely important.

See, you can't please everyone. So, you got to please yourself.

Being content with where you are and staying in one place, in a metaphoric sense, means your creative urge will atrophy and eventually be lost.

title: When Breath Becomes Air
review:
You can't ever reach perfection, but you can believe in an asymptote toward which you are ceaselessly striving.

You could not help but feel your speck-like existence against the immensity of the mountain, the earth, the universe, and yet still feel your own two feet on the talis, reaffirming your presence against the grandeur.

There is a moment, a cusp, when the sum of gathered experience is worn down by the details of living. We are never so wise as when we live in this moment.

Because the brain mediates our experience of the world, any neurosurgical problem forces a patient and family, ideally with a doctor as a guide, to answer this question: What makes life meaningful enough to go on living?

That to study philosophy is to learn to die.

Lucy and I both felt that life wasn't about avoiding suffering. Years ago, it had occurred to me that Darwin and Nietzsche agreed on one thing: the defining characteristic of the organism is striving.

Yet now, I felt that to understand my own direct experiences, I would have to translate them back into language. Hemingway described his process in similar terms: 'Acquiring rich experiences, then retreating to cogitate, and write about them.'

All knowledge is scientific knowledge. Yet the paradox is that scientific methodology is the product of human hands, and thus cannot reach some permanent ruth.

Science may provide the most useful way to organize empirical, reproducible data—but its power to do so is predicated on its inability to grasp the most central aspects of human life. Hope. Fear. Love. Hate. Beauty. Envy. Honor. Weakness. Striving. Suffering. Virtue.

No system of thought can contain the fullness of human experience.

title: Travels with Charley: In Search of America
review: Very full of heart, lots of beautiful writing. Unfortunately not much that stuck with me (looking back two months later)...not as powerful, gritty, or heart-wrenching as most of his other work. Still tackled a lot of important questions about human existence and our mundane little day-to-day-lives though.

title: Onward: How Starbucks Fought for Its Life without Losing Its Soul
review:
The world belongs to the few people who are not afraid to get their hands dirty.

Schultz is clearly a charismatic businessman, built for running companies—but the book was still full of much more corporate-speak and Wall Street than expected. Everything is cleaned up and packaged nicely in smooth business fashion, with obstacles being glossed over and analyzed from the always all-knowing lens of hindsight. Schultz never truly admits to any of Starbucks' failures and, of course, tries to sell off the company's corporate greed as social responsibility, but that's just what's to be expected from business I guess. The book was far too long and hard to get through. But Schultz is still a very good leader who gave very inspiring and valuable secrets to leadership in this book, echoing what other CEOs have also said in theirs. 

Belief in ourselves, and in what is right, catapults us over hurdles, and our lives unfold.

A well-built brand is the culmination of intangibles that do not directly flow to the revenue, or the profitability of a company, but contribute to its texture.

The question is always: How do you keep things in balance? Fiscal responsibility, and benevolence. Shareholder value, and social conscience. Profit, and humanity.

It's going to be lonely in the rain for a while, but you can make it.

Icons disrupt themselves before others disrupt them.

Enduring icons are willing to sacrifice near-term popularity for long-term relevance.

Ensuring that communication is narrow, clear, and repetitive to set expectations wins people's trust.

When did we stop hearing our own music?

I always trust my antennae to recognize people whose skill, knowledge, passion, and loyalty will align to serve Starbucks well, even if the person's resume might imply otherwise.

Any company, when faced with adversity, would be tempted to go forward with an idea that promises to quickly erase pain. 

But in business, as in life, people have to stay true to their guiding principles—to their cores.

title: Misery
review:
Yes, the work. The pride in your work. The worth of the work itself. All those things faded away into the magic lantern shades they really were when the pain got bad enough. 

A brave man could think. A coward couldn't. 

But in spite of the reputed fragility of the creative act, it had always been the single toughest thing, the most abiding thing in his life. Nothing had ever been able to pollute that crazy well of dreams. No drink, no drug, no pain. 

It was never for you, Annie. Or all the other people out there who signed their letters Your #1 Fan. The minute you start to write, all those people are at the other end of the galaxy or something. It was never for my ex-wives, or my mother, or my father. The reason authors almost always put a dedication on a book, Annie, is because their selfishness even horrifies themselves in the end. 

This man is a creative psychopathic genius. How is it even possible for a human mind to come up with things like this. This book is crazy, man... the scope. Very strangely autobiographical too.

Stephen King is definitely lucky that he is a good writer, otherwise he would be a high-security psychiatric ward patient.

title: The Alchemist
review:
Very inspiring (which I guess is the whole point). Big dreams, personal legend, law of manifestation... whimsical and full of love, matter-of-fact existence, & the scent of magic.

But also very cheesy too :' )

title: Death of a Salesman
review: Very real, raw, gritty tale of a tangle of human emotions. Perhaps a level of hotheaded-ness and conflict that was dramatized for effect (well, duh, it's a play) but nonetheless it has its roots in reality.

title: Empire of Pain: The Secret History of the Sackler Dynasty
review:
Fantastic writing and a veryyy interesting, shockingly true story about human greed. This guy is a *good* writer. Unequivocally good — I kept listening on not for the story but really just to witness the crunchy, good, satisfyingly fresh writing. He cleverly lets his reader do most of the thinking, never forcing a conclusion about the moral goodness or evil of the family (at least for the first 2 Books), which drew me in further. 
-1 star because I didn't enjoy how the final Book 3 forced more moral bias onto the reader (although I guess that was the whole point of this book) & also did not finish telling the story. :( Why couldn't Keefe have waited till the trials actually ended before publishing this book??? (I guess there might be many good reasons but still I wanna complain about it ... since it's much more vivid seeing the story unfold in his writing than in a dry news broadcast)

title: The Unbearable Lightness of Being
review:
A beautiful book filled with so many universal truths and too many mindblowingly good quotes. Serves as a very good reminder that the lightness which promises to bring such sweet relief from all the pains of living is in fact more dangerous than that seemingly wretched heaviness. At least what I got from it is that without anything to tie it down to its own unique qualities and give it shape, life becomes meaningless. I felt so much of this book helped me on a personal level specifically in the stage of life I happen to be at right now, but also sadly I had to remind myself a few times that the beautiful and fortuitous grace of this story is a curated illusion crafted carefully through one writer's artistic lens. 

It was a nice reminder to stop seeking high, lofty, shapeless nothings and instead to focus on the things that ground us, to keep ourselves humble in approaching life with a genuine appreciation for just the beauty of living.

title: Carrie
review:
But hardly anybody finds out that their actions really, actually hurt other people! People don’t get better, they just get smarter. 
When you get smarter you don’t stop pulling the wings off flies, you just think of better reasons for doing it. (98) 

Whenever anything important happens in America, they have to gold-plate it, like baby shoes. That way you can forget it. (117) 

King's world-building is fantastic. This book felt so personal and so real, sucking me right in.

title: Beloved (Beloved Trilogy, #1)
review:
A beautiful and masterful book - a real, raw account of life through Morrison's powerful poetic voice. Even if only based partly on a true story, it still carries the heavy weight of love: the freedom to choose to love, and the devastation of death to the loved. 

Three-dimensional, almost four-dimensional, portrayal of the horrors and inhumanity of slavery, with characters who are so real and so humanized by Morrison.

Morrison pulls on the heavy dilemma to love that (I think) we all feel: the fear that what we love will be broken by the world, scaring us into not wanting to love at all—to not get too attached to parts of this beautiful life, so that when they inevitably fail we won't be dragged down with them.  

Risky ... for a used-to-be slave woman to love anything that much was dangerous. Especially if it was her children she had settled on to love.

The best thing he knew was to love everything just a little bit. Just a little bit. 

So when they broke its back, or shoved it down a sack, then you'd still have a little love left over for the next one.

But, I want to say thank you to this book. It is really, really powerful. Morrison coaxes the desire, the courage, to love out of the reader again after these 10 hours (I listened to it as an audiobook. Highly recommend, because the author herself reads it with an energy no one else could). 

It's our choice to love. And life is beautiful, waiting to be beloved.

title: The House of the Spirits
review:
It was a real pleasure to see how truthfully Allende mirrored our 'real' world with the world of spirits. To describe how impactful this was for me, I need to steal a quote from Alan Watts' The Way of Zen:

Every positive statement about ultimate things must be made in the form of myth, of poetry. What can be described and categorized must always belong to the conventional realm.

This book certainly makes many statements about 'ultimate things.' I don't think I can put many of these things into words, but I want to try: to me this book was about the flow of life, the impact of recorded history, and the futile, yet inevitable, conflicts between the social strata that humans divide themselves into.

This last thing caused me the greatest inner turmoil (which is good - thank you, Sra. Allende, for making me uncomfortable and helping me think a little more about my own place in society). The book is told from the perspective of a bourgeoisie upper class family, which was all nice and lovely to read at first because I felt safe in the lavish luxuries that the characters enjoy - no danger of conflict or poverty yet. It's nice to (inevitably) empathize a little with the characters and pretend that you are the one building a massive villa with expensive furniture and a beautiful garden. However, once Esteban Trueba's empire starts to crumble and the revolt of the people occurs, the story swerves rapidly toward uncertainty and feelings of weakness, danger, and pain - it deepens, and here is where it left its mark on me.

You see Trueba reduced to a powerless old man, suffering a bitter loss of the wealth, connections, and political power he spent a lifetime amassing. At the end of the day he is just as desperate as any one of his tenants, whom he abused and treated like stupid animals. All he wants is the safety of his granddaughter Alba - love, at the end of the day, triumphed over all of the riches that he poured his blood and sweat into over the course of his life. So we really are all just the same. Peasants aren't stupid animals and patróns aren't magically elevated to the status of supreme, intellectual beings.

Ultimately, Allende reveals is no need for frustration, or hatred, or any hard feelings, at the way that events play out. Inner peace returns. Everything is part of the design created by the universe. And it is inevitable that one person's part in this design is crueler than others.

Esteban García is a part of the design. He is a crude, twisted line. But no brushstroke is in vain.

This book was a pretty refreshing treat to listen to. Even though it covers horrific torture and violent deaths, it still twinkles with spontaneity, fun, and a real, honest love of the world. This is what really brought the spirits to Clara del Valle Trueba - and to this wonderful book.

She did not believe that the world was a valve of tears, but rather a joke that God had played. And it was idiotic to take it seriously if he himself never had.

title: Blind Willow, Sleeping Woman
review:
Perfect kaleidoscope of Murakami—a collection with a nice, wide scope of variety. These stories are a beautiful escape into the world he creates.

I read this book before bedtime over the span of almost five months (I'm really sorry for taking so long, dear public library), so some of the stories have already slipped my mind by the time I'm writing this review. 

Which is a good thing, since the really beautiful and truthful ones have inevitably still stuck - making it a lot easier for me to pick them out and write about them! 

Here are the standout stars for me: (In general chronological order) 

- Hunting Knife 
- Dabchick
- The Year of Spaghetti 
- Fireflies (only pt. 1)  I'd already read this story in After the Quake, so I remembered the beginning very strongly and loved reading it again - however, I'd completely forgotten how it ended because the ending was a little too contrived/fragile, and not impactful :( 
- The Kidney-Shaped Stone That Moves Every Day 
- A Poor Aunt Story 

I'll write individual Goodreads listing reviews on each of the stories I found meaningful, since compiling them all here would make this review painfully long. 

Stories that I liked: (but that didn't really stick in my mind as strongly) 
-Blind Willow, Sleeping Woman 
-A Perfect Day for Kangaroos 
-Nausea 1979
-Tony Takitani
-The Rise and Fall of Sharpie Cakes
-The Ice Man 
-Crabs 
-Chance Traveler
-Where I'm Likely to Find It 
-A Shinagawa Monkey 

Stories I did not enjoy: 

-Fireflies (pt. 2 - the ending) 
         Strangely abrupt and too heavy on the symbolism of the 'firefly;' its unnaturalness (contrary to how Murakami's stories usually flow naturally) made it unenjoyable for me
-Hanalei Bay 
          This story also had a strange cadence that did not sit right with me. Time passed very unnaturally (e.g. ten years flash by in a single sentence), and to me the story was quite bland except for the few parts with important symbolism, which unfortunately felt too intentional to be impactful. Not really much of the usual mystique found in Murakami's stories. 

 Stories that I've already forgotten: (so I think they could be considered mediocre) 
-Birthday Girl 
-New York Mining Disaster 
-Airplane: Or, How He Talked to Himself as If Reciting Poetry 
-The Mirror 
-A Folklore for My Generation: A Pre-History of Late-Stage Capitalism 
-Man-Eating Cats 
-The Seventh Man 

 Final thoughts: 
Even though the number of standout stars was much smaller than the total number of stories (& there were quite a few mediocre ones), I'm still tipping the overall rating towards the positive side: 4 stars! (Even though the average of all these individual story ratings would probably be 3 stars) 

Reading this book (& a few stories in particular) still helped change my mind. It helped me discover powerful universal truths, hidden in the strange stories of tightrope-walking or cooking spaghetti. There were definitely several times when I put the book down to quickly dump thoughts/revelations into my notebook, feeling real, and visceral, connection to the message of a story. 

And finally, here's one of the quotes that was most powerful to me: 
Everything has its 'reasons' ... We just don't notice as we go about our lives. But then at some point we are made to notice ... it rocks you ... Everything, including a stone, knows everything that's inside you ... And all we can do is go with those things. As we take them in, we survive, and deepen.
- from The Kidney-Shaped Stone That Moves Every Day

title: Let Me Tell You What I Mean
review:
Out of all the short stories in this collection:

True standout star stories that I would have rated 5 stars separately:
Why I Write 
A Trip to Xanadu 

4 stars: 
Telling Stories 
Pretty Nancy 

Honestly all the others were just pretty good, though Joan Didion writes with a natural and arresting voice that feels so real.  The only story I did not enjoy was “Everywoman.com.” 

Why I Write especially changed the way I approach my own writing now. It's such a beautiful, naturally flowing story that tugs on emotions and experiences that I know from my own past - seeing myself in Didion's words was wonderful. (& maybe altered the course of my writing trajectory forever, delivering a much-needed slight shift?) It’s so chock-filled with pinnacle-of-truth advice that I wanted to highlight whole entire pages. 

I’d rate Joan Didion's masterful writing 5 stars, but unfortunately I have to rate the book overall only 3 stars because it feels like a pretty miserly grab for profit. The type spacing/margins felt quite weird - much too large, probably just trying to stretch out the short text into a sellable book-length thing. So future buyers beware, I guess.

Overall though, I'm glad I found this little book squished on a shelf at my local bookstore and took it home with me. That one story Why I Write was, at the moment in my life when I read it, exactly what I needed to prepare myself for the mountain of essay-writing that awaits me in these next few weeks. So honestly, those 12 thin book pages have redeemed the $24.99 price tag for this tiny little book.

(there’s another pro to this book though: I learned 17 new words while reading this because Joan Didion has the most awesome vocabulary!)

I write entirely to find out what I'm thinking, what I'm looking at, what I see and what it means. 
What I want and what I fear.
 from Why I Write

title: The Metamorphosis
review:
My first time in a while to have read a short story, but it did a nice job of sucking you right into Gregor's world. Little details of mundane life anchor the story (and also are a joy to savor); they help it seem a little more realistic, even when Gregor is undergoing incarceration in his room as a giant bug. 

Gregor's attachment to and love for (and pride in) his family is touching, relatable in its vulnerability. He had quite selflessly hurled himself at bearing the burden of money when asked, letting his family live off of his strained back. But after his bugification, they harbor a natural and quite strong disgust toward his bug form (even though their thoughts toward him stay mostly well-intentioned); poor Gregor. Clearly visible through their treatment of him, Gregor is no longer human. And he himself starts to become aware of his new wants and his new life metamorphosizing into an unknown yet acceptable bug normal. The unfortunate removal of his room's furniture snips his cherished ties to the memories and meaning of his life. Sadly, change in appearance and loss of communication have stripped all hope of connection to his family away from Gregor.

Gregor's metamorphosis draws out the true colors of his family. I found the father quite wicked, a character that spiked hate out of me with his wicked actions because poor Gregor's bug intentions were pure. His young seventeen year old sister is a good, naïve protector, although a little febrile and also inevitably repulsed by poor Gregor. But the family duty is still there- Gregor is still a member of the family. To be simply tolerated. 

A little sad to see the family dynamic - stubborn old father overshadowing gentler mother and young sister. 

 The things the world requires of poor people, they performed to the utmost, his father running out to get breakfast for the little bank officials, his mother hurling herself at the personal linen of strangers, his sister trotting back and forth behind the desk, doing the bidding of the customers, but that was as far as the strength of the family reached. 

And yet, just as Gregor gropes and mopes about his office job at the beginning, he gropes and mopes in his confinement when he no longer has to do the work at all. The burden falls onto the other three in the family (and the old charwoman). To go back to the start of the story, it was quite strange that Gregor seemed unfazed at first after waking up to his bugginess, only thinking complaints about his job to himself - but it was a good introduction to the somber gray shade of his life. Man can always find and magnify a nodule of unhappiness in his life. 

The welcoming of tenants into the flat helps draw a depressing contrast with Gregor's treatment as family. A little violin concert, played by the sister, is arranged in the living room for them and lures Gregor out of his dark, dirty room, enticed by the forgotten beauty of humanity. 

But poor Gregor's revelry sends the tenants stomping out furiously without paying a penny to their hosts. After all those months a true metamorphosis occurred in the minds of the sister and the parents. The body of Gregor has changed from him to it, a monster. Most strongly in the eyes of his sister, that innocent girl who had vainly asserted herself as Gregor's caretaker at first. 

But He thought back on his family with devotion and love. And the life leaves Gregor's shrunken body that night, laid belly up in his dirty little room. Finally, perhaps a true alleviation and metamorphosis for the family.

Warm sunshine enters the story for the first time, and in all those months slowly the family's prospects have become quite encouraging. With a bright young daughter, lively and ready for their new life. Strange transformation, after the work has been forced off of Gregor's weary shoulders onto theirs. 

Quite slow at the beginning, but worth the investment.
Overall: matter-of-fact, disciplined writing with no flashy distractions. Leaves solid bones for the mind to gnaw at later.

 A much better examination of this story to read: http://www.kafka.org/index.php?id=191,209,0,0,1,0 

Flaubert who loathed pretty-pretty prose would have applauded Kafka's attitude towards his tool

- Curiously enough, Gregor the beetle never found out that he had wings under the hard covering of his back.
- Kafka's art consists in accumulating on the one hand, Gregor's insect features, all the sad detail of his insect disguise, and on the other hand, in keeping vivid and limpid before the reader's eyes Gregor's sweet and subtle human nature.
- Gregor is a human being in an insect's disguise; his family are insects disguised as people. With Gregor's death their insect souls are suddenly aware that they are free to enjoy themselves.  'Come in beside us, Grete, for a little while,' said Mrs. Samsa* with a tremulous smile, and Grete, not without looking back at the corpse, followed her parents into their bedroom.'' The charwoman opens the window wide and the air has a certain warmth: it is the end of March when insects come out of hibernation.
-*In a note in his annotated copy Nabokov observes that after Gregor’s death it is never “father” and “mother” but only Mr. and Mrs. Samsa.
- “The soul has died with Gregor; the healthy young animal takes over. The parasites have fattened themselves on Gregor.”
